posts.title: Zoodles
posts.content:
Oodles of Zoodles

Zoodles = Zucchini Noodles.

But look! I also made sweet potato noodles! I guess that makes them Swoodles.

Zoodles and Swoodles slurp, taste and feel like real pasta noodles, except they are LOW CALORIE! Try it and you will become a believer!

Recipe:

1. Prepare the Zucchini & Sweet Potato Noodles

  • Wash a large zucchini, but you don’t have to peel it if you like the green colour in your pasta. Be aware that the peel contains a good portion of the zucchini’s vitamins and minerals, so eat the peel!
  • Place the zucchini in your Spiral Vegetable Slicer (refer to my photo) and turn the crank.
    • If you don’t have a spiral vegetable slicer, I strongly recommend you get one, especially considering they are only ~ $30. Otherwise, you can use a mandolin or a vegetable peeler, neither of which are as quick or as neat-o as the spiral vegetable slicer).
  • Wash and peel a medium-sized sweet potato. Place it into your Spiral Vegetable Slicer and turn the crank to make sweet potato noodles.

2. Cook it!

  • Toss the following onto a non-stick skillet on medium heat (use non-stick cooking spray) for ~3-5 minutes:
    • All of the zucchini noodles
    • 1 oz of the sweet potato noodles
    • 1.5 cup of mushrooms
    • 3 TBSP of Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free Pasta Sauce (I used Garlic & Herb)
    • 90g of shrimp (~3/4 of a cup). You can substitute with your favourite protein source (ie. chicken, tofu, scallops).

3. Garnish!

Garnish with freshly ground black pepper and calorie free Parmesan & Herb Seasoning. You can also substitute with 1 TBSP of Nutritional Yeast (which imparts a cheesy flavour).

Nutritional Information:

calories: 169, fat: 2g, saturated fat: 0.8g, cholesterol: 130 mg, sodium: 365.3mg, carbohydrates: 20.2 g, fiber: 4.1 g, sugars: 10.8 g, protein: 21.3g

posts.title: Ice Cream Float
posts.content:
Go Retro!

I bet you haven’t had an ice cream float in eons!

This is my new favourite recipe re-discovery! I’ll be making this all the time!

  • Quick, Easy and FUN to make!
  • Millions of flavour combinations (I provide 21 ideas at the end of this post)!
  • Delicious & Very Filling!
  • Only 90 calories!

Recipe:

Watch my QUICK video first, then read below.

1. Place the following into a Magic Bullet or Blender:

  • 1/2 scoop of BSN Isoburn Protein Powder (Vanilla Ice Cream Flavour)
  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk. I recommend SILK brand because it’s less calories.
  • 2 TBSP Walden Farms Marshmallow Dip (Calorie and Sugar free). It makes the ice cream “creamier”. You can omit this step if you prefer. Other thickening options would be 2 TBSP of non fat Greek Yogurt, Xanthan Gum or Glucomannan.

2. Place the mixture from step 1 into an ice cream machine. Please watch my ice cream machine tutorial to learn how to make ice cream without getting angry!

3. Place the following into a tall glass:

  • Half of your ice cream
  • Slowly pour the Zevia Cola. Add more Zevia once the fizz settles.
  • Mix the Zevia and Cola together with a spoon. Add more Zevia as needed
  • Top with the rest of your ice cream. Add more Zevia as needed.
  • Insert a straw from the side (not the centre). You want room for your ice cream to expand.

Enjoy!

Nutritional Information:

  • calories: 90, fat: 3.6g, saturated fat: 0.5g, cholesterol: 5mg, sodium: 270mg, carbohydrates: 4g, fiber: 1.8g, sugars: 1g, protein: 10.8g

Flavour variations:

  • BSN Isoburn comes in strawberry, vanilla and chocolate.
  • BSN Syntha-6 comes in 14 flavours!
  • Zevia comes in 15 flavours! It’s sweetened with Stevia. I recommend the rainbow pack so you can experiment!

  • You could also use Sparkling Ice! It comes in 17 flavours!

  •  My ideas:
    • Root beer Float: Zevia Root Beer & BSN Isoburn Vanilla Ice Cream
    • Orange Creamsicle Float: Zevia Orange & BSN Isoburn Vanilla Ice Cream
    • Reverse Orange Creamsicle Float: Zevia Cream Soda & BSN Syntha-6 Orange Smoothie
    • Apple Pie Float: Sparkling Ice Crisp Apple & BSN Isoburn Vanilla Ice Cream with a pinch of Nutmeg and Cinnamon
    • Pumpkin Pie Float: Zevia Cream Soda and make the ice cream with BSN Syntha 6 Cinnamon Bun, canned pumpkin, nutmeg & cinnamon.
    • Cookies & Cream Float: Zevia Cream Soda & BSN Syntha-6 Cookies & Cream
    • Peaches & Cream Float: Sparkling Ice Peach Nectarine & BSN Isoburn Vanilla Ice Cream
    • Strawberries & Cream Float: Zevia Strawberry & BSN Isoburn Vanilla Ice Cream
    • Reverse Stawberries & Cream Float: Zevia Cream Soda & BSN Isoburn Strawberry Milkshake
    • Strawberry Lovers Float: Zevia Strawberry & BSN Isoburn Strawberry Milkshake
    • Strawberry Banana Float: Zevia Strawberry & BSN Syntha-6 Banana
    • Keylime Pie Float: Zevia Lime & BSN Isoburn Vanilla Ice Cream
    • Chocolate Cherry Float: Zevia Black Cherry & BSN Isoburn Chocolate Milkshake
    • Chocolate Lovers Float: Zevia Cola or Cream Soda & BSN Isoburn Chocolate Milkshake
    • Chocolate Mint Float: Zevia Cola & BSN Syntha-6 Chocolate Mint
    • Chocolate Coffee Float: Zevia Cola & BSN Syntha-6 Mochaccino Ice Cream
    • Chocolate Peanut Butter Float: Zevia Cola & BSN Syntha-6 Chocolate Peanut Butter
    • Peanut Butter & Jelly Sandwich Float: Zevia Grape & BSN Syntha-6 Peanut Butter Cookie
    • Citrus Float: Zevia Lemon Lime Twist or Grapefruit Citrus & BSN Syntha-6 Orange Smoothie
    • Tropical Fruit Punch Float: Sparkling Ice Kiwi Strawberry & BSN Syntha-6 Orange Smoothie
    • Hawaiian Fruit Punch Float: Sparkling Ice Coconut Pineapple & BSN Syntha-6 Orange Smoothie
  • Note: the Isoburn versions are Suitable for Alternate-Day Fasting (ie. for your “down days”).

Ingredient Information:

posts.content:
Watch This!

You Know You Want This

  • Chocolate & Peanut Butter
  • Quick & Easy
  • Creamy & Delicious

Recipe:

Blend and Enjoy!

posts.title: Quinoa Sweet Potato Patties
posts.content:
This Recipe is a Winner!

Congratulations to Jodie Stephens-Quintero! She won my Recipe Contest!

Her Prize: This recipe feature on my website PLUS a Bodybuilding.com “Be Awesome” tank top!

Thank you to all the ladies who entered! Now we have tons of new mouth-watering recipes to add to our yummy repertoire! Thank you Brandi Bartmess and Tammy Walsh for helping me organize, promote and judge this contest! Go #TeamSS!

Recipe:

(makes 2 patties)

  • 1/2 cup of cooked quinoa. Click here to learn how to cook it and measure it.
  • 1/2 of a cooked skinless medium sweet potato (mashed)
  • 1/2 cup of chopped kale
  • 1/4 cup chopped onion (*onion can be sautéed before adding to mixture depending on preference)
  • 1 egg

Mix all ingredients. Form 2 patties.  Place both patties in a skillet (medium heat) using 1 TBSP of coconut oil*. Brown for approximately 1-2 minutes on each side.

*Friendly reminder: If you use coconut oil, then make sure you add this into your final calories. I recommend using PAM nonstick cooking spray, unless you want to factor an extra 130 calories and 14 grams of fat of coconut oil into your daily caloric intake! The coconut oil changes this recipe from 278 calories and 7.3 g of fat to 408 calories and 21.3 g of fat!  DO NOT ASSUME THAT OLIVE OIL OR COCONUT OIL ON YOUR SKILLET DO NOT COUNT TOWARDS YOUR DAILY INTAKE! If you are not losing weight following my system, then maybe it’s time to take a closer look at what you are putting in your mouth compared to what you are tracking for your daily calories. Do you have to demonize olive oil and coconut oil? Absolutely not! But you do have to count it towards your calorie input! Download my eBook, Fat Loss Fast 1 to learn how to establish and track your calories and macros.

Nutritional Information:

This is using PAM non-stick cooking spray (and not coconut oil). This is for BOTH patties:

  • calories 278, fat: 7.3g, saturated fat: 1.6g, cholesterol:195mg, sodium: 105.9mg, carbohydrates: 42.4g, fiber: 6.4, NET CARBS: 36g, sugars: 7.6g, protein: 13.3g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Chicken Artichoke Flat Bread
posts.content:
10-Minute Protein Flatbread!

Walden Farms Garlic & Herb sauce combined with cooked chicken, artichokes, mushrooms, spinach and P28 High Protein Flat Bread makes this delicious meal so quick and easy!

Flexible Dieting!

I’ve been eating P28 bread products since August 2013 and nothing has happened to me. I fit it into my macros and I’m maintaining my lean physique… except I’m happy! I’m eating bread! Download my eBook, Fat Loss Fast 1: Immediate Kick-Start to Flexible Dieting & Intermittent Fasting to learn how to start flexible dieting immediately.

Recipe:

1. Pre-heat oven to 350 degrees F

2. Cook the Chicken:

  • I baked my chicken breast in the oven at 400 degrees F for 35-40 minutes. Feel free to prepare your chicken your favourite way (skillet, steamer, boil, BBQ, etc).

3. Put it all Together

  • Spray a cookie sheet with PAM non-stick cooking spray.
  • Using scissors, cut one P28 Flat Bread into 6 rectangles (see photo).
  • Lay the 6 flat breads on the cookie sheet
  • Paint the tops of each flat bread with Walden Farms Garlic & Herb Sauce (~2 TBSP)
  • Distribute the following toppings over the 6 flat breads: 1/8 cup of spinach, 1/4 cup of cremini mushrooms, 1 artichoke heart, 1.5 oz of chicken. Season (I used black pepper and Club House’s calorie free Parmesan & Herbs Seasoning).
  • Place in the oven for ~8 minutes. Keep an eye on the crust (don’t burn it!).
  • ENJOY!

Nutritional Information:

For my entire recipe:

  • calories 325, fat: 8.8g, saturated fat: 0.5g, cholesterol:28.1mg, sodium: 532.7mg, carbohydrates: 29.8g, fiber: 6.6, NET CARBS: 23.2g, sugars: 5.6g, protein: 38.9g

Compare this to the same portion of the Outback Steakhouse’s Chicken Artichoke Flatbread:

  • calories 410, fat: 18g, saturated fat: 7g, cholesterol:55mg, sodium: 970mg, carbohydrates: 31g, fiber: 3, NET CARBS: 28g, sugars: 3g, protein: 25g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

posts.title: Alternate Day Pancakes
posts.content:
Attention Alternate Day Fasters!

Pancakes every day! Huh? How? What? Keep reading!

If you follow my approach to Alternate Day Fasting, that means you fast for 36 hours on alternating days. The good news is that you don’t have to eat zero calories during these 36 hours (which are referred to by Dr. Johnson as “Down Days”). After 20 hours have elapsed, you can eat <500 calories worth of lean protein and vegetables. For more information about Intermittent Fasting, please sign up for my FREE Fasting Tutorials!

Not everyone wants to eat chicken on their “Down Days”. So here is a low calorie, low carb, low fat option for people with a sweet tooth! It uses 2 lean protein sources: egg whites and BSN ISOBURN Fat-burning Protein Powder Matrix.

“Down Day” Pancake

This recipe is FLUFFY & DELICIOUS! I used it again on my “Up Day”, except I added dark chocolate chips! YUM!

“Up Day” Pancakes

Then I became even fancier and added Sugar Free Jell-O Butterscotch Instant Pudding!

“Up Day” Butterscotch Pudding Pancakes

Recipe:

1. Blend the following in a Magic Bullet (or blender) to create the pancake batter:

  • 1/2 scoop of BSN ISOBURN Whey in Vanilla Ice Cream
  • 1/2 cup of egg whites
  • 2 giant globs (~3 TBSP) of Walden Farms Marshmallow Dip (Calorie Free/Sugar Free). This makes it fluffy!

2. Place the batter onto a non-stick skillet over medium heat (or use non-stick cooking spray). Flip the pancake (with a big spatula) after a few minutes (when you can see the bottom has turned golden brown). Cook the opposite side for a few minutes until it also turns golden brown.

  • If it’s your “Up Day”, then add 1 tsp >70% Chocolate Chips.
  • If it’s your “Down Day”, then immediately skip to step 3.

3. Plate the pancake and drizzle with Walden Farms Calorie Free Pancake Syrup!

==>For the butterscotch pudding pancakes: Use the same recipe except:

  • Blend 1 package of Sugar Free Jell-O Instant Pudding (butterscotch) with 1 cup of unsweetened almond milk in a clean Magic Bullet. Set aside 1/2 of the portion for the pancake topping. Then add the same ingredients into the Magic Bullet for the pancake batter, except use 3/4 cups of egg whites.

Nutritional Information:

==>for the Down Day Pancake

  • calories: 120, fat: 1g, saturated fat: 0.3g, cholesterol: 5mg, sodium: 375.8mg, carbohydrates: 2.5g, fiber: 1g, NET CARBS: 1.5g, sugars: 1g, protein: 24g

==>for the Up Day Pancake (with chocolate chips)

  • calories: 150, fat: 3g, saturated fat: 1.3g, cholesterol: 5mg, sodium: 376.5mg, carbohydrates: 4.8g, fiber: 1.3g, NET CARBS: 3.5g, sugars: 2.7g, protein: 24.3g

==> for the Up Day Butterscotch Pudding Pancakes

  • calories: 310, fat: 5.6g, saturated fat: 1.5g, cholesterol: 5mg, sodium: 1851.5mg, carbohydrates: 30.3g, fiber: 2.1g, NET CARBS: 28.2g, sugars: 2.7g, protein: 32.1g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Cheesy Omelette (Dairy Free)
posts.content:
Dairyarrhea

I understand that many of us cannot eat dairy without getting dairyarrhea.

Yep, I relate. Here’s my dairy diary.

  • Milk gives me milkarrhea.
    • No problem: I can substitute with unsweetened almond milk
  • Cheese is yummy, but if I eat it, I will be leaving “farting gifts” everywhere!
    • No problem: I can substitute with:
      • Daiya Dairy Free Cheese or
      • Nutritional Yeast

So I made this Dairy Free Omlette. And it is an O.M.G (Omelette Made Great). You would never guess in a million years I used “faux cheese”. Yep, I just saved you from Omelerrhea!

Dairy Free, Gluten Free, High Protein, Low Carb, Low Fat

Recipe:

  1. Spray a non-stick skillet (with a lid) with PAM non-stick cooking spray (medium heat).
  2. Add 2 cups of spinach, 5 sliced cherry tomatoes & 1 cup of peppers (any colour you want: I used red, orange and yellow).
  3. Add 1 cup of egg whites
  4. Add 1/8 cup of Daiya Dairy Free Cheese Shreds. I like the Pepperjack flavour! OR add 1 TBSP nutritional yeast.
  5. Mix it all around and then close the lid. This technique simultaneously cooks both sides. Once cooked, you can fold it in half or leave it like a big flat pancake.
  6. Season with black pepper and Mrs. Dash
  7. Enjoy!

Simmer Down, Pot Roast!

  • I’m not running a dictatorship. These are just ingredient options. You can substitute. For example, you can use the entire egg and not just the egg whites. Use mushrooms instead of peppers. Use Kale instead of spinach. You get the point!
  • Do you want to know the reasons why I give you a recipe with precise quantities and ingredients?
    • So I can provide you with precise nutritional information
    • So it looks like the picture
    • Just in case you are bereft of culinary skills

Nutritional Information:

Note: I calculated this using Daiya Cheese, not the nutritional yeast.

  • calories 206, fat: 2.1g, saturated fat: 0.6g, cholesterol:0mg, sodium: 530.6mg, carbohydrates: 15.6g, fiber: 4.6, NET CARBS: 11.0g, sugars: 6.6g, protein: 32.2g

What is those Ingrediences?

I type english grate.

Learn about the ingredients I used in this recipe, including the Daiya Dairy Free Cheese & Nutritional Yeast in my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

posts.title: Peanut Butter Cup Bottom Cheesecake
posts.content:
QUESTion!

What’s better than cheesecake? A Cheesecake with a Quest Peanut Butter Cup Bottom!

Recipe:

Step 1: Add the following to a large bowl and mix with an electric hand mixer for 2 minutes:

  • 1 package of Jell-O Sugar Free Cheesecake Instant Pudding & Pie Filling
  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk

Step 2: Cottage Cheese is optional!

  • I added 4 TBSP of low fat cottage cheese and mixed it into the pudding with the electric hand mixer. The reasons are twofold:
    • Because the cheesecake filling was  TOO SWEET for me! Made my head shake!
    • Because cottage cheese has casein protein. Casein protein is a slow-releasing protein, making it a perfect protein choice for an intermittent faster’s last meal during his/her eating window.

Step 3: Dissect the  Peanut Butter Cups

  • Use a fork to scoop out the insides of 2 Quest Peanut Butter Cups (see photo). It creates mini bowls!
  • Place half of the “scoopings” into the cheesecake pudding. Save the other half for the topping.
  • Place the PB Cups into muffin paper cups in a muffin tray
  • Scoop the pudding mixture on top of each PB cup (Use 1/4 of the pudding per PB cup). See Photo.
  • Place the PB cup shavings on top of each cheesecake for decoration. Then place the muffin tray in the freezer for about 1 hour and 40 minutes. I had no issues removing the paper liner… it came off like a prom dress!
  • Place the other half of the pudding mixture into the fridge. Save it for another recipe or eat it later! You could add it to a shake or an ice cream recipe!

Nutritional Information:

I ate one cheesecake and saved the other one in the freezer for another day. It is very decadent.

For 1 cheesecake:

  • calories: 167, fat: 9.3g, cholesterol: 4.4mg, sodium: 469.7mg, carbohydrates: 11.8g, fiber: 3.2g, sugars: 0.8g, protein: 13.2g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

For more Yumminess!

Check out my “OMG Quest Nutrition Dessert Recipes eBook“!

posts.title: Coffee Crisp Ice Cream
posts.content:
How Do you Like Your Coffee?

Crisp!

Coffee Crisp is a Canadian chocolate bar.  It consists of alternating layers of vanilla wafer and foamed coffee-flavoured soft candy, covered with a milk chocolate outer layer. It’s also available as “bites” and as ice cream!

The bad news: Coffee Crisp is high in sugar, fat and calories and devoid of fibre and protein. The good news: I made a low calorie, low sugar and high protein version of the Coffee Crisp Ice Cream! And it tastes exactly like Coffee Crisp! Look!

Before You Begin:

Step 1: Buy an Ice Cream Machine. I got mine at the rainforest place for ~$50 here. Best thing money can buy. I use mine ALL the time except when I don’t use it.

Step 2: Watch my “How to Use an Ice Cream Machine Tootorial Video” or just read my instructions here.

Recipe:

Place the following into a Magic Bullet or Blender:

  • 1/2 scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Mochaccino Whey
  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk. I recommend SILK brand because it’s less calories.
  • 1/2 cup of crushed ice
  • 2 TBSP Walden Farms Marshmallow Dip (Calorie and Sugar free). It makes the shake “creamier”. You can omit this step if you prefer. Other options would be 2 TBSP of low fat cottage cheese, Xantham Gum or Glucomannan.
  • 1/2 tsp vanilla extract

Blend and then add:

  • 2 TBSP All Bran Buds Cereal

Add this mixture to your ice cream machine (turn the machine ON before adding the mixture). It takes about 15-20 minutes in the machine. Once it’s ready, turn off the machine and immediately remove the ice cream from the ice cream bowl.

Enjoy!

Nutritional Information:

(for the entire recipe)

  • calories: 145, fat: 5.8g, saturated fat: 1.2g, cholesterol: 27.5g, sodium: 316.4mg, carbohydrates: 12g, fiber: 4.6g, NET CARBS: 7.4g, sugars: 2.1g, protein: 12.1g

Compare this to a Coffee Crisp Chocolate Bar:

  • calories: 250, fat: 13g, saturated fat: 8.0g, cholesterol: 0g, sodium: 55mg, carbohydrates: 32g, fiber: 0g,, sugars: 25g, protein: 2g

Compare this to conventional Coffee Crisp Ice Cream (1 cup)

  • calories: 320, fat: 16g, saturated fat: 14g, cholesterol: 50g, sodium: 110mg, carbohydrates: 40g, fiber: 0g,, sugars: 30g, protein: 2g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Orange Julius
posts.content:
Whey Better!

Why have a conventional Orange Julius Shake, which has 106 grams of sugar and only 1 g of protein, when you could have my knock-off version? My version is the same quantity; however, it has 59% less calories, 98% less sugar and 94% more protein!

Recipe:

Place the following into a Magic Bullet or Blender:

  • 2/3 scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Orange Smoothie Whey
  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk. I recommend SILK brand because it’s less calories.
  • 1/2 cup of crushed ice
  • 2 TBSP Walden Farms Marshmallow Dip (Calorie and Sugar free). It makes the shake “frothier”. You can omit this step if you prefer. Other thickening options would be 2 TBSP of non fat Greek Yogurt, Xantham Gum or Glucomannan.
  • 1/2 tsp vanilla extract

Blend and Serve! Tastes exactly like Orange Julius!

Nutritional Information:

(for the entire shake)

  • calories: 169, fat: 6.6g, saturated fat: 1.6g, cholesterol: 40g, sodium: 291.8mg, carbohydrates: 8.4g, fiber: 2.7g, NET CARBS: 5.7g, sugars: 2.9g, protein: 15.4g

Compare this to the same size Orange Julius Shake

posts.title: Mexican Chicken
posts.content:
Mexican Chicken!

I make this recipe all the time! Chicken can get very boring very fast. This gives it a nice zip! Plus you benefit from the high fibre content of the black beans, if you know what I mean

Recipe:

I present 2 options for this recipe: either your oven or your Crock Pot!

Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F

Place the following into an oven friendly glass dish.

  • 2 uncooked skinless chicken breasts (I used smaller sized breasts, so when cooked, this is ~8oz)
  • 1/2 cup black beans (no sodium added)
  • 1 cup of sliced bell peppers (any colour is fine … or use your favourite veggies)
  • 10 sliced cherry tomatoes
  • 1/2 cup salsa (try to find a lower sodium option)
  • 1/4 cup Daiya Dairy Free Cheese (substitutions: 2-3 TBSP nutritional yeast or use 1/4 cup skim cheese)
  • Season with black pepper, salt-free Mrs. Dash, etc. I also used dehydrated onion flakes.

Place it into the oven for 30-35 minutes (depending on your oven, you may need more or less time).

Another option is to use your Crock Pot (Slow Cooker). My Crock Pot was ~$30, which is within my “kitchen gadget budget”!

This is easy! Just dump the ingredients into your slow cooker (I sprayed mine with PAM non-stick spray first) and I used the low setting for about 4 hours (I checked it periodically). Just follow the instructions for your slow cooker. Here’s a peek inside my crock pot!

Nutritional Information:

For half of the recipe (ie. 1/4 cup black beans, 4 oz chicken, 1/8 cup Daiya, 1/2 cup red peppers, 1/2 cup green peppers, 5 cherry tomatoes, 1/4 cup of salsa)

  • calories: 277, fat: 5.6g, saturated fat: 1.1g, cholesterol: 75mg, sodium: 643.6mg, carbohydrates: 26.5g, fiber: 8.4g, net carbs: 18.1g, sugars: 9.5g, protein: 31.7g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: PB2 Blondies
posts.content:
Black Beans are Back!

Black Beans are my secret baking weapon:

  • It’s a SWEET Bean!
  • VERY high in fibre!
  • You can substitute flour in your brownies, blondies, pancakes and cookies recipes with black bean puree.
    • If your recipe calls for 1/2 cup of flour, then use 1/2 cup of black bean puree instead.

Easy Recipe

Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F

Mix the following in a magic bullet (blender):

  • 1 egg
  • 1/2 cup of black beans (no sodium added). Rinse them under cold water in a strainer first.
  • 1/2 scoop of Peanut Butter Cookie Syntha-6 Whey
  • 2 TBSP of PB2 (used regular, but feel free to use chocolate PB2)
  • 2 TBSP of  Walden Farms Calorie Free Pancake Syrup
  • 1/4 tsp baking soda
  • Then add 1 tsp >70% Chocolate Chips

Spray non-stick cooking spray in a small oven-friendly baking pan (see photo). Place in the oven for 18-25 minutes. Verify the blondies are cooked in the centre with the “toothpick test”.

Cut them into squares to create ~6 blondies.

Nutritional Information:

For the entire recipe:

calories: 313, fat: 10.8g, saturated fat: 3.3g, cholesterol: 232.5mg, sodium: 420.7mg, carbohydrates: 29.8g, fiber: 12.3g, net carbs: 17.5g, sugars: 4.2g, protein: 24.8g

I ate half of the recipe (157 calories), and placed the leftovers in the fridge for another day. It’s really yummy and moist!

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Chocolate Haystacks
posts.content:
Hay Hay!

This is a great NO BAKE recipe to keep you regular! Protein Chocolate Haystacks!

Recipe:

Mix the following together in a bowl:

  • 1/3 scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Whey in Chocolate Cake Batter
  • 3 TBSP of Walden Farms Calorie Free Pancake Syrup
  • 1/2 cup Fibre 1 Cereal
  • 1 TBSP reduced fat unsweetened coconut

Place parchment paper (or plastic wrap) over a plate. Make ~6-7 Haystacks. Place in the freezer to set for 20 minutes. Eat!

Nutritional Information:

(for the entire recipe)

calories: 175, fat: 4g, saturated fat: 1.9g, cholesterol: 18.3g, sodium: 254.5mg, carbohydrates: 32g, fiber: 17.2g, NET CARBS: 14.8, sugars: 0.7g, protein: 9.6g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

All-Bran vs. Fibre 1:

I can’t help but notice that fibre 1 has no sugar. It also has less sodium, more fibre, and less fat than the same size portion of All-Bran.

I’m keen to increase my insoluble fibre (to help with regularity), but I’m not keen about the 7 grams of sugar in All-Bran. I realize the Fibre 1 is sweetened with splenda, but I have no issues with this. It’s up to you to make the right choices for yourself.

Canada vs. USA Labelling

In Canada, we call spell it fibre. In the USA, it’s fiber. WHTA? I mean WHAT?

Notice identical products have different labelling in Canada vs. the USA.

  • In the USA, 1/2 cup of Fiber 1 has 60 calories.
  • In Canada, 1/2 cup of Fibre 1 has 90 calories.
  • In the USA, a banana nut muffin Quest Bar has 170 calories
  • In the USA, a banana nut muffin Quest Bar has 190 calories

In the USA, the insoluble dietary fiber calories are subtracted from the total calories. Why? Because in theory, the body doesn’t burn insoluble fiber. When fiber is listed as a part of a food’s total carbohydrate content, it’s counted at 4 Calories per gram, just like all other carbs.

posts.title: PB2 All Bran Bars
posts.content:
Constipation:

I’m going to be very honest. I have had issues with regularity since childhood. I finally spoke to my doctor about it. She advised I stop taking senna containing products (ie. tea and pills), which I confessed to her I have been taking for years. It turns out senna is indicated for treatment of short-term constipation only. It works by irritating the lining of the bowel, which causes a laxative effect.  Long-term use of senna can actually cause the bowels to stop functioning normally and may even cause dependence on laxatives!*

Rather, she told me to include psyllium fibre in my diet. She recommended either All-Bran Cereal or Metamucil. Considering both have calories, I’d rather eat my fibre than drink it, so I opted for All Bran Cereal.

All-Bran New

Fiber cannot be digested. There are 2 types of fiber: soluble and insoluble.

All-Bran Buds contain psyllium fibre, which is a type of soluble fibre. Soluble fibre dissolves in water to make a gel-like substance. This substance delays the speed at which food passes through your intestines. It also contributes to healthy cholesterol levels and helps regulate blood sugar levels*.

All-Bran Buds also contain wheat bran, which is an insoluble fibre (“roughage”). Wheat bran is very effective in promoting regularity. It passes through the digestive system largely unchanged, and increases the speed at which the “bulked” undigested food moves through the large intestine*.

Check out my low calorie, low fat bars! They have a nice CRUNCH to them. Please note: these are not gluten free. I don’t have an intolerance to gluten, and therefore, I do not demonize it!

Easy Recipe:

  • Place 1/3 of a cup of All-Bran Buds into a bowl
  • Add 3 TBSP Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free Pancake Syrup
  • Add 2 TBSP PB2 (watch my PB2 video taste test and review below)
  • Add 1 tsp of >70% dark chocolate chips (optional)

Mix these ingredients together and then pack them firmly into a small dish lined with plastic wrap (for ease of removal).

Place in the fridge for a couple of hours to set it. If you are impatient, place it in the freezer for 20-30 minutes. Then cut and serve!

Nutritional Information:

The entire recipe (including the chocolate chips) is:

  • calories 145, fat 4g, saturated fat 1g, cholesterol 0mg, sodium 311.9mg, carbohydrates: 30.3g, fiber 12.3g, net carbs: 18g, sugars: 11.7g, protein 7.3g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

 What is PB2? 

Watch my PB2 taste test/product review video. Find more information about PB2 here.

Final Thoughts:

Here is my progress photo, which was taken after I included All Bran into my diet for the week. Clearly everything is ok! Plus I’m more regular and happier! At the end of the day, you have to make dietary choices that work for your body and sanity. It’s not a big deal for me to add All Bran Cereal to my diet because I can factor it into my daily macros and calories, thanks to my flexible dieting and intermittent fasting system.

posts.title: Cauliflower Couscous (Plus a Sushi Bonus)!
posts.content:
Faux Rice Couscous and Sushi!

I tried to make cauliflower rice sushi, and it was an epic fail. (see video below).

Thankfully, Ashleigh Kearely (who has lost all the baby weight using intermittent fasting & flexible dieting), came to my rescue and made a video tutorial to explain how to make cauliflower rice sushi! (see video below).

But my failed attempt was not a total loss because it helped me devise a new recipe! CAULIFLOWER COUSCOUS!

Recipe:

Combine the following into a bowl and serve:

  • 2 cups of blended raw cauliflower florets (to mimic rice)
    • Blend the cauliflower florets in a food processor or use a grater.
  • 1 TBSP calorie free Bragg Soy Sauce alternative (or you could use low sodium chicken broth)
  • 4 oz Shrimp
  • 1 sheet of Nori Paper (rip it into tiny pieces)
  • 1 cup of sliced cucumber
  • Your favourite salt-free seasoning.

Nutritional Information:

(for the entire couscous recipe)

calories: 156, fat: 2.1g, saturated fat: 0.7g, cholesterol: 206.7mg, sodium: 848.8mg, carbohydrates: 15.5g, fiber: 4.6g, NET CARBS: 10.9g, sugars: 5.7g, protein: 25.7g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

Cauliflower Sushi Recipes:

Presenting Ashleigh’s masterpiece!

My epic fail: (it’s hilarious):

Ashleigh’s sushi success!

  •  sushi rolling equipment (recommended by Ashleigh). Watch her video below to learn how to use it.

Bonus! Miracle Rice Sushi!

I was curious to see if I would be able to get Miracle Rice to cooperate. It worked, thanks to Ashleigh’s technique. Don’t be fooled by my pretty picture. It was messy to make!

Recipe:

This recipe makes 2 rolls:

  • Prepare the calorie free Miracle Rice as per package instructions. I find this too time consuming. I just place the miracle rice in a strainer and rinse it for a minute, then I place it in the microwave for a minute. BUT, before I toss it in the microwave, I add seasoning to give it flavour. If you want to just eat it as rice, I recommend adding  calorie free Walden Farms alfredo pasta sauce to give it flavour. (see photo).

  • Add half of the rice to 1 nori sheet.
  • Add your favourite sushi ingredients. I used tuna and cucumber.
  • Roll and slice into maki (as per Ashleigh’s video instruction). I really struggled with this (it was messy!). If I did it again, I wouldn’t bother slicing it. I’d just toss it all into a bowl like the couscous recipe.

Nutritional Information:

(for 2 rolls)

calories: 80, fat: 2.1g, saturated fat: 0.7g, cholesterol: 26.6mg, sodium: 48.7mg, carbohydrates: 3.4g, fiber: 0.2g, NET CARBS: 3.2g, sugars: 0.5g, protein: 15.9g

“Rice” OPTIONS:

White Rice, Brown Rice, Cauliflower Rice, Miracle Rice, Alfalfa Sprouts

posts.title: Chocolate Chip Black Bean Pancakes
posts.content:
BLACK BEANS!

Did You Know?

  • It’s a SWEET Bean!
  • VERY high in fibre!
  • You can substitute flour in your brownies, pancakes and cookies recipes with black bean puree. If your recipe calls for 1/2 cup of flour, then use 1/2 cup of black bean puree instead.

Recipe:

  • It only takes 5 minutes to make!
  • It’s so good you will relish every morsel

1. Mix the following in a magic bullet:

  • 1/2 cup egg whites
  • 1/4 cup uncooked black beans (no salt added). Rinse them with running water in a strainer first!
  • 1/2 scoop of BSN Lean Dessert Protein in Chocolate Fudge Pudding
  • 2 TBSP of Calorie Free Walden Farms Marshmallow Fluff Dip (Makes it fluffy and yummy!)
  • Then add 1 tsp >70% Chocolate Chips

2. Place the batter onto a non-stick skillet over medium heat (or use non-stick cooking spray). Flip the pancake (with a big spatula) after a few minutes (when you can see the bottom has turned golden brown). Cook the opposite side for a few minutes until it also turns golden brown.

3. Plate the pancake and drizzle with Walden Farms Calorie Free Pancake Syrup

Nutritional Information:

posts.title: Cheesy Garlic Cauliflower Breadsticks
posts.content:
Are YOU bReady?

Faux Breadsticks are the best thing since sliced bread!

  • Made with Cauliflower!
  • Low Carb
  • Dairy Free
  • Gluten Free
  • Tastes like Bread … but is a fraction of the calories, carbs, fat and guilt!

Ingredients:

  • 1  cauliflower head (6-7″)
  • 2 eggs
  •  3/4 cup of Daiya Dairy Free Mozzarella Style Shreds (or you can use nutritional yeast)
  • A dash of dehydrated minced garlic flakes
  • Salt Free Mrs Dash Garlic & Herb Seasoning

optional:

  • 1 TBSP of Molly McButter butter sprinkles. (Don’t freak out! It’s not dairy free, and if you don’t like this product, then don’t use it!) I added Molly McButter because it tasted Molly McBetter.
  • Toast the breadsticks to make them crunchy

Video Recipe:

Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F.

Watch the video to learn the recipe.

Nutritional Information:

This makes a very large portion! I cut it into 20 breadsticks. I ate 1/3 of it (~6 to 7 slices), and saved the rest in the fridge for another day.

This is the macronutrient breakdown for 1 slice (1/20th of recipe):

  • calories: 31, fat: 1.5g, saturated fat: 0.5g, cholesterol: 19.5mg, sodium: 64.1mg, carbohydrates: 3.2g, fiber: 1g, net carbs: 2.2g, sugars: 0.8g, protein: 1.6g

Compare this to 1 slice of Pizza Hut’s Breadsticks with Cheese:

  • calories: 170, fat: 7g, saturated fat: 3g, cholesterol: 13mg, sodium: 15 mg, carbohydrates: 20g, fiber: 1g, net carbs: 19g, sugars: 2g, protein: 8g

So you can have 6 of my cauliflower breadsticks, or you can have 1 breadstick from Pizza Hut!

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

FAQ:

I made this batch of Cheesy Garlic Cauliflower Breadsticks on Sunday night. (Jan. 19).

It’s Tuesday (Jan. 21), and I added more seasoning and toasted them. Still tastes great!

So yes, you can store them in the fridge for a few days and toast ‘em up! Look!

posts.title: Chicken & Mushroom Risotto
posts.content:
Miracle Risotto!

COMFORT FOOD is now a CLEAN CHEAT thanks to Miracle Rice and Walden Farms Alfredo Sauce! Both of these products are calorie free!

Does cheese give your the squits? No worries! I offer dairy-free cheese options! Keep Reading…

Recipe: 

1. Make the Chicken

If you don’t know how to make chicken, then buy a roasted chicken in your grocery store. Otherwise, toss your chicken breast on the skillet or in the oven. Heck, you could even boil it.

2. Slap Everything in the Skillet

Dump all of this into your skillet (coated in PAM) on your stove top (medium heat):

  • 1 bag Miracle Rice (Rinse the rice in a sieve first to annihilate the fishy flavour)
  • 1 cup sliced Cremini or White Button Mushrooms
  • 1/2 cup black beans (no salt added). Rinse off the gooey bean juice in a sieve first. I love black beans because they taste good and are high in fibre.
  • 1/4 cup Walden Farms Calorie Free Alfredo Sauce
  • 1/4 cup of Daiya Dairy Free Mozzarella Style Shreds (or you can use 1 TBSP nutritional yeast) … or skim cheese.
  • 1 TBSP dehydrated onion flakes
  • A dash of garlic flakes
  • A dash of ground rainbow pepper corns (or just use black pepper)
  • Add 6 oz of the cooked chicken last.

EAT!

Nutritional Information:

This makes a very large portion! I ate it all because YES!

  • calories: 360, fat: 9.2g, saturated fat: 2g, cholesterol: 112.5mg, sodium: 615mg, carbohydrates: 24.5g, fiber: 10g, net carbs: 14.5g, sugars: 1.5g, protein: 45.5g

Compare this to the same size portion of Chicken Mushroom Risotto ordered in a restaurant:

  • calories: 832, fat: 33g, saturated fat: 11.6g, cholesterol: 90.2mg, sodium: 1811mg, carbohydrates: 87.2g, fiber: 7.8g, net carbs: 79.4g, sugars: 6.4g, protein: 63g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Cauliflower Mashed Fauxtatoes
posts.content:
Fauxtatoes vs. Potatoes!

OMG! You have to try my Cheesy Garlic Mashed Fauxtatoes!

I made mine with a secret ingredient! Cauliflower! Oh, and I swear you cannot taste the cauliflower!

Compared to conventional mashed potatoes, an equal portion of my fauxtatoes are:

  • 62% less calories!
  • 73% less fat!
  • 70% fewer NET carbs!
  • Equally DELICIOUS!

Note: I provide Dairy-Free Substitutions in my Recipe!

Recipe

1. Cook your Cauliflower:

I recommend purchasing pre-cut/washed cauliflower florets in a convenient bag for easy microwave steaming.

You can also bake your cauliflower in the oven.  This is not a dictatorship. Do whatever blows your skirt up. If you elect to bake ‘em in the oven, then preheat your oven to 400 degrees F. (Note: My oven sucks like 17 vacuums, so your oven is probably better  at 350 degrees).

  • Wash and cut a head of cauliflower. This yields ~4 cups.
  • Spray butter-flavoured PAM non-cook cooking spray in an oven-friendly pan.
  • Add the cauliflower. Bake in the oven for ~30 minutes.

I personally prefer steaming them in my skillet (just fill it with water and cauliflower and close the lid until the cauliflower is soft).

2. Mash your Cauliflower:

  • Dump the 4 cups of cooked cauliflower into a food processor.
  • Blend it to start breaking up the huge cauliflower florets.

3. Add the Flavour:

You don’t want your mashed potatoes to taste like cauliflower, do you? Hells no! So add flavour to the food processor:

  • 4 TBSP of chicken broth (no salt added or low sodium)
  • 1/8 cup of Daiya Dairy Free Mozzarella Style Shreds (or you can use 1 TBSP nutritional yeast)
  • 1 TBSP dehydrated onion flakes
  • A dash of garlic flakes
  • A dash of ground rainbow pepper corns (or just use black pepper)
  • 2 tsp of Molly McButter butter sprinkles. (Don’t freak out! It’s not dairy free, and if you don’t like this product, then don’t use it! At least you get the butter flavour from the PAM when roasting the cauliflower. Another option is to add more cheese and seasoning).

Puree the daylights out of this. I unloaded the dishwasher while mine was in the food processor.

EAT!

Nutritional Information:

This makes a very large portion! I ate half of it (~1 cup), and saved the other half in the fridge for another day.

This is the macronutrient breakdown for 1/2 of the portion:

  • calories: 95, fat: 2.6g, saturated fat: 0.7g, cholesterol: 0mg, sodium: 210.2mg, carbohydrates: 16.1g, fiber: 6.2g, net carbs: 9.9g, sugars: 6.1g, protein: 5.2g

Compare this to 1 cup of homemade mashed potatoes made with potatoes, cheese, milk and butter.

  • calories: 250, fat: 9.64g, saturated fat: 3.44g, cholesterol: 13mg, sodium: 672 mg, carbohydrates: 35.36g, fiber: 2.9g, net carbs: 32.46g, sugars: 3.61g, protein: 6.17g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

BONUS! 

For St. Patrick’s Day, I use GREEN CAULIFLOWER!

posts.title: Double Chocolate Chip Cheesecake Fudge
posts.content:
OMG!

Question: What happens when you combine fudge, cheesecake and chocolate?

Answer: The tastiest thing in the world! Double Chocolate Chip Cheesecake Fudge!

Whoa!

  • 4 pieces of my fudge = 3.8g sugar
  • 4 pieces of conventional fudge = 67.3 g sugar

Recipe:

  • It only takes 3 minutes to make and 20-30 minutes to set!
  • It’s so good you will do a little jig when you bite into it!

1. Mix the following by hand in a bowl:

  • 1 TBSP coconut butter
  • 1 tsp low fat cottage cheese
  • 1/2 scoop of BSN Lean Dessert Protein in Chocolate Fudge Pudding
  • A sparing amount of water (just enough to moisten the ingredients). You want it to be thick (see photo below).
  • Then add 1 tsp >70% Chocolate Chips

2. Line a small dish with plastic wrap (see photo above)

3. Pour the mixture into the dish. Mold it into a rectangular prism shape.

4. Place in the freezer for 20-30 minutes.

5 .Once set, remove from freezer. I cut mine into 4 cubes. EAT IT ALL!

Nutritional Information:

calories: 203, fat: 12.8g, saturated fat: 9.5g, cholesterol: 25.6mg, sodium: 71.7mg, carbohydrates: 10.5g, fiber: 4.1g, net carbs: 6.4g, sugars: 3.8g, protein: 12.8g

posts.title: Mint Chocolate Chip Ice Cream
posts.content:
Screw Chicken, I want Protein Ice Cream!

Man, this ice cream is mint! (That was a double entendre: mint as in “excellent” and mint as in a “flavour”).

Everybody knows that mint chocolate chip ice cream is the best ice cream flavour in the world. Anyone who does not like mint chocolate chip ice cream either has broken taste buds or no life, or both.

Sick of relying on chicken for your protein source? Then it’s time for a mintervention!

Before You Begin:

Step 1: Buy an Ice Cream Machine. I got mine at the rainforest place for ~$50 here. Best thing money can buy. I use mine ALL the time except when I don’t use it.

Step 2: Watch my “How to Use an Ice Cream Machine Tootorial Video” or just read my instructions here.

Recipe:

Blend the following in a Magic Bullet or Blender:

  • 1 cup Silk Brand Unsweetened Vanilla Almond Milk
  • 2 TBSP Walden Farms Calorie Free Marshmallow Dip
  • 1/2 scoop of BSN Syntha-6  Chocolate Mint Protein Powder

Add this mixture to your ice cream machine (turn the machine ON before adding the mixture)

  • Then add 1 tsp >70% Chocolate Chips

It takes about 15-20 minutes in the machine. Once it’s ready, turn off the machine and immediately remove the ice cream from the ice cream bowl.

Enjoy!

Nutritional Information:

calories: 160, fat: 7.6g, saturated fat: 2g, cholesterol: 27.5mg, sodium: 295.7mg, carbohydrates: 10.8g, fiber: 3.6g, net carbs: 7.2g, sugars: 2.7g, protein: 12.1g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Tiffany’s Banana Bread
posts.content:
Cheat Clean & Stay Lean This Holiday Season!

Never fear! Sara and Tiffany will satisfy your sweet cravings this holiday season … with nutritious banana bread recipes! Our easy recipes are low in sugar and carbs!

Who is Tiffany Stanley?

  • She is my drop dead gorgeous friend.
  • She’s a top Irish model, reality TV star and actress.
  • She regularily graces the covers and pages of Ireland’s most popular publications.
  • She makes one hell of a delicious and nutritious banana bread!
  • She  practices Intermittent Fasting and Flexible Dieting!
  • She has a HOT HOT HOT calendar you can get here
  • Follow her on Instagram, Twitter and her website.

Tiffany’s Banana Bread!

Bake until golden at about 180 degrees Celsius and test with a knife, it’s fully cooked when the knife runs clean.

Sara’s “Remix” of Tiffany’s Banana Bread:

Preheat your oven to 400 degrees F

Mix the following in a large bowl:

  • 2 mashed ripe bananas
  • 1 cup almond flour
  • 1/4 cup coconut flour
  • 2 TBSP extra virgin coconut oil
  • 1/2 cup egg whites
  • 1/2 cup Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free Pancake Syrup
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 2 TBSP dark chocolate chips (>70%)

Place into a silicone loaf pan sprayed with PAM and bake for ~35 minutes. Do the toothpick test to confirm it is fully cooked.

Nutritional Information:

This yields a pretty large loaf. I cut it into 8 generous pieces.

For 1/8th of the loaf (ie. one piece):

  • calories: 159, fat: 10.6g, saturated fat: 4.5g, cholesterol: 0mg, sodium: 56.7mg, carbohydrate: 11.3g, fiber: 3.9g, net carbs: 7.4g, sugars: 4.8g, protein: 5.2g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

posts.title: Ice Cream Machine Tutorial
posts.content:
Tootorial:

Today I teach you how to use an ice cream machine. I don’t want to sound like I’m tooting my own toots again, but I also teach you how to make FREAKIN YUMMY Ice Cream…

Chocolate Chip Cheesecake S’mores Ice Cream

Ingredients:

  • 1 scoop Bodybuilding.com Foundation Series 100% Casein (Chocolate)
  • 1 cup Silk Brand Unsweetened Vanilla Almond Milk
  • 1 TBSP Low Fat Cottage Cheese
  • 1 TBSP Walden Farms Calorie Free Marshmallow Dip
  • 1 TBSP Walden Farms Calorie Free Pancake Syrup
  • 1 TBSP GG Scandinavian Bran Fiber Flakes
  • 1 TBSP >70% Chocolate Chips

Equipment:

  • Magic Bullet
  • Cuisinart Ice Cream Machine

Video Recipe Demo:

Watch the video to learn my recipe and how to use an ice cream machine

Nutritional Information:

calories: 234, fat: 7.7g, saturated fat: 2g, cholesterol: 46.9mg, sodium: 296.3mg, carbohydrates: 12.5g, fiber: 2.8g, sugars: 4.9g, protein: 29.4g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

How to Make Ice Cream:

Method 1:

  1. Remove your ice cream bowl from the freezer (you are supposed to keep it in the freezer all the time… and at least for 24 hours before the first time you use it. Yeah, I was pretty angry about waiting 24 hours the first time too). Set the bowl onto your ice cream stand and assemble the ice cream maker according to the directions. Turn it on! It must be on before you add your ice cream mixture!
  2. Pour the ice cream mixture into the spinning ice cream machine (approximately $50) for ~15 minutes. Keep an eye on it.

Method 2:

If you don’t have an ice cream machine, you can use the “ziploc bag” technique.

  • Stuff a HUGE Ziploc bag half-full with ice. Add 6 TBSP of Kosher Salt  (or rock salt) and mix.
  • Add all the ingredients used in the desired recipe (see below) into a small Ziploc bag and seal it.
  • Bury the small Ziploc bag inside the salty ice in the large Ziploc bag. Seal the large bag.
  • Shake the bags vigorously for 5-15 minutes until ice cream forms! (hold with a towel to prevent frost bite).
    • Note: When you add salt to the ice, it lowers the freezing point of the ice, so more energy has to be absorbed from the environment for the ice to melt. This makes the ice colder than it was before, which is how your ice cream freezes.
    • Note: Kosher & rock salt have larger crystals than table salt. Larger crystals take longer to dissolve in water around the ice, which allows for even cooling of the ice cream.

posts.title: Chicken Alfredo Protein Pizza
posts.content:
Easy Pizza!

Walden Farms Creamy Alfredo sauce combined with cooked chicken and P28 flat bread makes this pizza so quick and easy!

I Eat Bread!

I’ve been eating P28 bread products since August 2013 and nothing has happened to me. I fit it into my macros and I’m maintaining my lean physique… except I’m happy! I’m eating bread! Look at me if you need evidence!

Because of my approach to flexible dieting and Intermittent Fasting, I’m happy and lean! If you are not losing fat anymore and you feel deprived, then it’s time for you to download my Fat Loss…Fast e-Book: Immediate Kick-Start to Flexible Dieting and Intermittent Fasting!

Recipe:

1. Pre-heat oven to 400 degrees F

2. Make the Cheesy Alfredo Sauce: Mix the following into a bowl

  • 1.5 tsp Nutritional Yeast
  • 2 TBSP Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free Alfredo Pasta Sauce

3. Cook the Chicken:

  • I baked my chicken breast in the oven at 400 degrees F for 35-40 minutes. Feel free to prepare your chicken your favourite way (skillet, steamer, boil, BBQ, etc).

2. Make the Pizza Crust:

  • Spray a cookie sheet with PAM non-stick cooking spray. I used a silpat mat, sprayed with PAM.
  • Get a big bowl and place it over one P28 Flat Bread. Trace a circle around the bowl with a knife. Remove the borders (see photo).
  • Lay the crust  flat on the cookie sheet
  • Top with the Alfredo Sauce, 1/2 cup of cremini mushrooms, 3 sliced cherry tomatoes, 2.5 oz of chicken. Season (I used black pepper and green onion flakes).
  • Place in the oven for ~8 minutes. Keep an eye on the crust (don’t burn it!).
  • ENJOY!

Nutritional Information:

For my entire pizza:

  • calories 364, fat: 8.4g, saturated fat: 0.5g, cholesterol:46.9mg, sodium: 433.3mg, carbohydrates: 32.1g, fiber: 7.1, NET CARBS: 25g, sugars: 7.5g, protein: 47.2g

Compare this to 1/8th of a slice of Olive Garden’s Chicken Alfredo Pizza:

  • calories 380, fat: 16g, saturated fat: 8g, cholesterol:30mg, sodium: 950mg, carbohydrates: 36g, fiber: 2, NET CARBS: 34g, sugars: 3g, protein: 15g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

posts.title: Apple Pie Protein Ice Cream
posts.content:
Tastes Like Pie! But Better!

Remember this?

Now forget about it because I made something better!

My apple pie ice cream is half the calories! Plus it’s high in protein, low in fat, low in sugar and YUMMY! Look at it….

How to Make Ice Cream

Click here to learn! It’s easy!

Recipe:

Place the following into a blender (I used the tall 16 oz Magic Bullet cup)

  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk (note: you can substitute with coconut milk, which will make the ice cream even creamier).
  • 1/2 scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Whey (Cinnamon Bun flavour)
  • 1 TBSP Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free Pancake Syrup
  • 1 TBSP low fat cottage cheese (this makes it creamy … but you can omit this if desired).
  • 1/2 of a 4 oz container of unsweetened applesauce (the single serving containers)
  • 1/4 cup of water (to create a bigger yield because who doesn’t like big portions?).
  • pinch of nutmeg
  • pinch of cinnamon

Pour this mixture into your ice cream machine for 10-15 minutes.

Turn off the machine and immediately scoop the ice cream into a dish before it sticks to the ice cream bowl!

Add 1/4 of an apple (cut it into small cubes). I used a Gala apple. Drizzle with more Pancake Syrup, as desired.

Nutritional Information:

Sara’s BSN Version:

  • calories: 189, fat: 5.7g, saturated fat: 1g, cholesterol: 34.4mg, sodium: 270.6mg, carbohydrates: 20.9g, fiber: 5.5g, Net Carbs: 15.4g, sugars: 10.5g, protein: 14.9g

Haagen Dazs’ Version (equivalent portion):

  • calories: 500, fat: 28g, saturated fat: 16g, cholesterol: 130mg, sodium: 220mg, carbohydrates: 56g, fiber: 0g, Net Carbs: 56g, sugars: 48g, protein: 6g

Ingredient Information:

The recipes in my eBook will make you say OMG! YUM and FA LA LA LA LA! Don’t believe me? Well then try these recipes! They were also featured on Bodybuilding.com!

Pumpkin Pie Fudge and Chocolate Pumpkin Bark!

Pumpkin Pie Fudge:

2. Line a small dish with plastic wrap.

3. Pour the mixture into the dish. Mold it into a rectangular prism shape.

5 .Once set, remove from freezer. I cut mine into 12 cubes. EAT IT ALL!

posts.title: Protein Dessert Wonton Cups
posts.content:
No Origami Required

Don’t worry. I’m not going to make you fold food a million times until it becomes a seahorse.

I Eat Bread!

I’ve been eating P28 bread products since August 2013 and nothing has happened to me. I fit it into my macros and I’m maintaining my lean physique… except I’m happy! I’m eating bread! Because of my approach to flexible dieting in combination with Intermittent Fasting, I’m  lean! Look at me:

Recipe:

1. Pre-heat oven to 400 degrees F

2. Make the Wontons:

  • Spray the BOTTOM side of a muffin tray with PAM non-stick cooking spray
  • Get scissors and cut one P28 Flat Bread into 4 squares. Put 2 squares back into the freezer for another day.
  • Refer to the photo for the next steps.

3. Make the Chocolate Yogurt: Mix the following in a bowl

  • 1/2 cup nonfat Plain Greek Yogurt
  • 1/2 scoop BSN Syntha-6 Isolate (Chocolate Milkshake). Feel free to try other flavours too!

Place the chocolate yogurt into each wonton.

4. Top with fresh strawberries.

Note: you can fill your wontons with anything! chicken salad, fruit, Chocolate PB2, protein ice cream, etc.

Nutritional Information:

For BOTH cups (including the strawberries)

posts.title: Protein Nachos & Chocolate Dip
posts.content:
A High Calorie Recipe for Intermittent Fasters:

Many of you who are intermittent fasting have been complaining to me that you have a hard time “eating ALL your calories” during a 4 or 8 hour eating window. You write to me saying, “Sara, I’m struggling to eat that much in a short amount of time”.

Really? I’ve never had that problem! I could eat everything AND MORE during my 4 hour eating window! lol.

Nevertheless, I heard your complaint, and devised this 400-calorie recipe because it will help you reach your caloric goals quickly and easily with just one snack! Plus it has ~40 grams of protein!

I Eat Bread!

I’ve been eating P28 bread products since August 2013 and nothing has happened to me. I fit it into my macros and I’m maintaining my lean physique… except I’m happy! I’m eating bread!

Because of my approach to flexible dieting in combination with Intermittent Fasting, I’m happy and lean! Look at me!

I Eat Carbs at Night! OMG!

Yes! I pig out on carbs at night! But I’m an intermittent faster, so I am not eating any carbs (or any food!) during the morning and afternoon.

According to a 2011 study in the journal Obesity, consuming most of your carbs at dinner leads to greater weight loss. Why? Eating carbs at night will induce a single daily insulin secretion in the evening. This will boost leptin levels 6 to 8 hours later, which will contribute to enhanced satiety during the next day’s fasting window.

  • NOTES: I am an intermittent faster who only eats between 5 and 9pm. So this high carb recipe is an example of what I would eat towards the end of my eating window (eg. between 7 and 9pm)

Recipe:

1. Pre-heat oven to 400 degrees F

2. Make the Tortillas:

  • Spray a cookie sheet with PAM non-stick cooking spray
  • Get scissors and cut one P28 Flat Bread into zillions of little triangles (see photo)
  • Lay them flat on the cookie sheet
  • Place in the oven for 4 minutes and then turn the oven off… just leave them in the oven for another 3-4 supervised minutes until they are crispy (don’t burn them!)

3. Make the Chocolate Banana Peanut Butter Dip: Mix the following into a bowl

  • 1/2 a mashed medium banana
  • 3 TBSP nonfat Greek Yogurt
  • 1 TBSP original or chocolate PB2
  • 1/4 scoop BSN Syntha-6 Whey (Chocolate Cake Batter Flavour)

ENJOY your Nachos & Dip!

Note: you can use many options for your dip, such as salsa, guacamole or hummus.

Nutritional Information:

  • calories 412, fat: 9.2g, saturated fat: 1.1g, cholesterol: 13.8mg, sodium: 492.5mg, carbohydrates: 49.1g, fiber: 9.3, NET CARBS: 39.8g, sugars: 16.1g, protein: 40.6g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Protein Ice Cream Crêpes!
posts.content:
Holy Crêpe it’s an IceCreamergency!

It’s a BSN Party in my mouth! So friggin’ awesome, insanely sweet, better than Capt’N Crunch!

It’s guilt-free so go ahead and eat the hell out of it. I did. I even licked the plate.

I can’t stop yumming in my head about it. Dang! Just looking at the picture is enough to evoke feelings that transcend natural arousal and segue into an unusual sort of hunger.

Now all you’ll need is a little dessert upstairs, if you know what I mean…

Behold the Ice Cream Crepes:

I made 3 versions… and I’m sure you will devise some fancy versions too.

  1. chocolate strawberry
  2. chocolate blueberry
  3. chocolate peanut butter cup

I bet chocolate banana, chocolate cherry or chocolate raspberry would be amazing too. What’s your fruit of choice?

Version 1: chocolate strawberry ice cream crepe

 

Version 2: chocolate blueberry ice cream crepe

Version 3: chocolate peanut butter cup Ice Cream Crepe

 

Ingredients from Bodybuilding.com:

One stop shopping, baby! Hells Yeah!

  1. BSN Syntha-6 Isolate (Chocolate Milkshake Flavour)
    • Just the thought of it is enough to make me lose my mind.
  2. Walden Farms Calorie Free and Sugar Free Syrup in Strawberry, Blueberry & Chocolate Flavours.
    • Throw away your calorious syrup…or else I’m calling the calorie cops.
  3. Quest Cravings Protein Peanut Butter Cups

Recipe:

=>Make the Ice Cream: Click here to learn! It’s easy!

Place the following into a blender (I used the tall 16 oz Magic Bullet cup)

  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk (note: you can substitute with coconut milk, which will make the ice cream even creamier).
  • 2/3 scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Isolate  (chocolate milkshake flavour)
  • 1/2 cup strawberries
    • for version 2: use 1/2 cup of blueberries
    • for version 3: use 1 cup of peeled raw zucchini. I suggest you add 1 TBSP of the calorie free syrup to further sweeten the ice cream (so you don’t detect any zucchini). I suggest you blend the crap out of the zucchini to make a puree because you don’t want zucchini chunks in your ice cream, do you?
  • 1/4 cup of water (to create a bigger yield because who doesn’t like big portions?).

Pour this mixture into your ice cream machine for 10-15 minutes.

bird’s eye view of my ice cream machine.

=>Make the Crêpe

1. Combine the following into a cyclone cup (shaker cup) or magic bullet and blend:

  • 1/2 cup egg whites
  • 1/3 scoop BSN Syntha-6 Isolate (Chocolate Milkshake)
  • Optional: dash of cinnamon

2. Heat a medium-sized non-stick skillet (use a skillet with a lid or use a “Flip Jack Pan“) over medium heat. Spray lightly with non-stick cooking spray (PAM).

3. Once the pan is heated, pour batter in the center of the skillet and quickly spread the batter evenly over the bottom of the skillet using a circular tilting motion.

  • Place the lid on the skillet to cook the crepe on both sides. (NOTE: It cooks fast).
  • Flip the crepe when bubbles in the batter have popped (ie. when the top is set). At this time, the bottom of the crepe should be browned. Carefully Flip the crepe (use a large spatula or a pancake turner), and cook it until the bottom side starts to brown (~ 1 minute).

4. Plate the crepe

=>Combine Everything

  • Slather 1 TBSP of the Chocolate Syrup & 1 TBSP of the Strawberry Syrup over the crepe.
    • version 2: use Chocolate Syrup & Blueberry Syrup
    • version 3: use Pancake Syrup and top with 1 Quest Nutrition Peanut Butter Cup! I split mine in half.
  • Plop the Ice Cream on top of the crepe. Feel free to slather more calorie free syrup on the ice cream. Why not? This is anarchy!
  • Eat!

Nutritional Information:

Sara’s BSN Version 1:

  • calories: 253, fat: 4.3g, saturated fat: 0.2g, cholesterol: 15mg, sodium: 590.7mg, carbohydrates: 14g, fiber: 4.2g, Net Carbs: 9.8g, sugars: 5.5g, protein: 40.2g

IHOP’s Version:

  • calories: 460, fat: 21g, saturated fat: 10g, cholesterol: 90mg, sodium: 250mg, carbohydrates: 65g, fiber: 3g, Net Carbs: 62g, sugars: 31g, protein: 6g

=> Everyone eating the fattening IHOP version can pack their saddlebags and go home.

ps. This is IHOP’s Version:

 

IHOP’s Ice Cream Fruit Crepe 

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Toothsome Treats
posts.content:
Chew on This!

Here is a toothsome Hallowe’en treat that won’t cause Hallowbetes (diabetes) or tooth decay!

Now at first glance, you may think I used marshmallows. Did you really think I’d use sugary marshmallows? Everyone knows that marshmallows are ghost poo.

Read below to find out the “marshmallow alternative” I used…

Recipe:

  • 1 Gala apple: cut and carve into lip shapes (optional: create a cupid’s bow in the upper lip).
    • Note: Apples have low glycemic index rating, which means the rate at which the apple is formed into glucose and released into your bloodstream is much slower.  This is good because it will help keep your blood sugar levels under control. 
  • Cut La Nouba Marshmallows (fat free, no sugar, no carbs) into teeth shapes (use scissors)
  • Stack 6 marshmallows onto the lower lip, then rest the upper lip on top.
  • Use 1 TBSP of P28 White Chocolate Spread to make the marshmallows and apples stick together.
    • Note: combining a healthy fat (such as nut butter) with your apple will slow the release of glucose into your bloodstream, which well help keep your blood sugar levels as stable as possible.
    • Substitutions: You could also use PB2 (to save calories), all natural peanut butter, or almond butter. 

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

Nutritional Information:

(for 1 apple, 2 marshmallows and 1 TBSP P28 spread):

calories: 208, fat: 6.5g, saturated fat: 0.5g, cholesterol: 0mg, Sodium 0mg, carbohydrates: 35.5g, fiber: 6.5g, NET CARBS: 19g, sugars: 18.5g, protein: 7.4g

Diabetes & Dentistry:

Good oral hygiene is paramount for many reasons other than just preserving your smile. A growing body of research suggests that gum disease plays a role in diabetes(1). So if you have diabetes, remember to consult with your dentist because dentistry for diabetics can require extra care.

A Few Facts about Type 2 Diabetes & Dentistry:
1. Did you know type 2 diabetes can increase the risk for gum disease?

  • Inflammation creates an interaction between obesity, diabetes and gum disease. Fat cells produce cytokines that trigger insulin resistance, which can lead to type 2 diabetes. Diabetes, in turn, increases the risk for gum disease. And new research suggests that gum disease can affect a diabetic’s ability to control blood sugar levels.   Exercise, proper nutrition and periodontal treatment to reduce the level of inflammation in the teeth’s surrounding tissues are three measures to help improve blood sugar control in type 2 diabetics(2).

2. Did you know it is often the dentist who first discovers a larger health problem? For example, diabetics tend to develop periodontal disease at three to four times the rate of non-diabetics. If a dental professional sees gum inflammation in someone who brushes and flosses regularly, they need to ask, “Have you checked your blood sugar lately?” (2).

3. Oral health has to be a part of general health care.  Maintaining oral hygiene can help prevent more serious conditions from developing in the body. Treating and preventing gum disease is possible with daily brushing and flossing in addition to regular cleanings and check-ups with a dental professional(3).

KEY POINT: People with diabetes are more likely to develop gum disease, which in turn can increase blood sugar and diabetic complications.

References:

1. Guynup Sharon.  Our Mouths, Ourselves. Oral and Whole Body Health. New York: Scientific American. 2006, p.3-5 (http://www.dentalcare.com/media/en-AU/products/owbh.pdf)

2. Genco J Robert.  The Three-Way Street. Oral and Whole Body Health. New York: Scientific American. 2006, p.18-22 (http://www.dentalcare.com/media/en-AU/products/owbh.pdf)

3. Kagan, Robert.  Mouthful of Bugs. Oral and Whole Body Health. New York: Scientific American. 2006, p.46-48 (http://www.dentalcare.com/media/en-AU/products/owbh.pdf)

posts.title: Bloody Quest Eyeballs
posts.content:
Eye Carumba!

My Halloween Recipes are getting cornea and cornea. No need to lash out at me.

Ingredients & Materials:

  • 1 Quest Bar. I used “vanilla almond crunch”  (the eyeballs)
  • Plastic wrap
  • 2 blueberies (irises)
  • 2 cacao nibs (pupils)
  • Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free STRAWBERRY Syrup (bloodshot eyes)
  • 2 mini forks for dramatic effect

Wicked Witches of the Qwest

Procedure:

  • Cut 1 Quest bar (Vanilla Almond Crunch) into half. Place on a plate covered with plastic wrap (otherwise the Quest Bars will stick to your plate). Place in the microwave for 15 seconds. Once removed from the microwave, roll each half between your palms to make a ball. Make a depression in each ball for the blueberries (each blueberry will be an iris).
  • Coat the 2 balls in the vanilla whey icing. Make this icing by adding 1/2 a scoop of BSN ISOBURN whey (vanilla ice cream) with a very small amount of water.
  • Place the blueberry in each depression.
  • Place the cacao nib in each blueberry (These are the pupils).
  • Scatter each eyeball in “blood” using Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free STRAWBERRY Syrup.
  • Stab a mini fork into each eyeball base for dramatic effect.
  • Place in the fridge to set for 10 minutes.

Nutritional Information:

For both eyes:

  • calories: 263, fat: 9.6g, saturated fat: 0.5g, cholesterol: 7.5mg, sodium: 482.1mg, carbohydrates: 23.5g, fiber: 18.1g, net carbs: 5.4g, sugars: 1.3g, protein: 32.5g

Mom & Taz dressed up for Halloweek.

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

Watch the Video Taste Test!

This video stars me, my mom and Taz! We are the Wicked Witches of the Qwest!

posts.title: Edible Used Q-tips
posts.content:
EARIE!

These are earie (I mean eerie) and gross (but Healthy) Hallowe’en Treats! Freak out your kids and friends this Halloweek!

Used Q-tips are the perfect way to enhance the “gross factor” at your Hallowe’en event!

Used Q-tips are:

  • Low in sugar and carbohydrates
  • Gluten free
  • Diabetic and tooth friendly
  • A source of protein and “healthy” fat
  • An intelligent alternative to conventional sugary hallowe’en treats that cause tooth decay!
  • Quick and easy to make

Recipe:

  • Tear off a small portion off marshmallow from the white segment of a La Nouba Marshmallow.  These marshmallows have no sugar, no carbs, no fat and no gluten.
    • Available in America here: La Nouba Marshmallows
    • Available in Canada here: La Nouba Marshmallows
  • Place the marshmallows onto the ends of a lollipop stick and mould it with your fingers to look like a Q-tip
  • Dip the ends of the marshmallows into the “ear wax” (see “ear wax” recipe below)
  • Place in the fridge/freezer for a few minutes to dry the “wax”
  • Place the edible Q-tips in an empty Q-tip box for your guests
Ear Wax Recipe (it’s delicious and eerie!)
  • 1/3 scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Cinnamon Bun Whey
  • 1 tsp of all natural peanut butter (or for a lower fat and lower calorie option, use PB2)
  • Mix the whey and the peanut butter together using a sparing amount of water to achieve a waxy consistency

Watch the video demo:

Nutritional Information:

Fo 1 Q-tip:

calories: 14.5, fat: 0.3g, saturated fat: 0.1g, cholesterol: 3.2g, 13.75, carbs: 1.9g, fiber: 0.1g, sugars: 0.2g, protein: 1.65g

Don’t Run! I never liked fast food…

posts.title: Finger Food
posts.content:
Sugarless Hallowe’en Quest:

Trick your kids (and yourself!) into eating less sugary treats this hallowe’en. Here’s how to avoid Hallobetes:

 

I love Hallowe’en

Ingredients & Materials:

  • 2 Quest Bars. I used cinnamon roll for the 4 digits and strawberry cheesecake for the bloody thumb
  • Plastic wrap
  • 5 almonds
  • Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free STRAWBERRY Syrup
  • A Glove and a Knife, for dramatic effect

Did I mention I love Hallowe’en?

Procedure:

Cut the Quest Bar into Quarters

  • Cut 1 Quest bar into quarters (see the photo). Place on a plate covered with plastic wrap (otherwise the Quest Bars will stick to your plate). Place in the microwave for 18 seconds. Once removed from the microwave, roll each quarter between your palms to make a finger shape. I even pinched the fingers to mimic human anatomy, and I used a knife to carve “knuckle lines”.
  • Place the fingers to look like a hand. Place an almond on the fingertips to mimic fingernails.
  • Cover the with a glove (I folded the fingers down).
  • Break off a chunk (1/4) of another Quest bar and roll it to look like a thumb. I used a strawberry cheesecake bar to make it look bloodier. I didn’t bother microwaving it because it was very fresh and malleable. Dip the thumb stump in blood (Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free STRAWBERRY Syrup). Place an almond on the thumb tip.
  • Coat the knife and plate with “blood” (Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free STRAWBERRY Syrup) for dramatic effect.

I designed these shoes for my Vampire Costume. How freakin’ awesome are these?

Nutritional Information:

For 1 and 1/4th of the above-mentioned Quest Bars plus 5 almonds and 1 tsp Syrup:

  • calories: 244, fat: 10.2g, saturated fat: 0.2g, cholesterol: 6.3mg, sodium: 342.1mg, carbohydrates: 31.6g, fiber: 22g, net carbs: 9.6g, sugars: 1.7g, protein: 26.3g

Oct 20 2013 – progress photo. Intermittent Fasting is working great!

posts.title: Monster Eyeballs for Halloween (turkey meatballs)
posts.content:
Scare the family this Hallowe’en with creepy turkey meatballs that stare back at you!

Easy Recipe:

(makes 12 turkey meatballs):

Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F

In a bowl, combine the following and mix by hand:

  • 1 package of extra lean ground turkey (12 oz)
  • 1 TBSP minced onion (you can use dehydrated onion flakes to save time)
  • black pepper
  • 1/4 cup minced green pepper (chop chop!)
  • 1 TBSP Nutritional Yeast Seasoning(To impart a cheesy flavour: click here to read my article about the health benefits of Nutritional Yeast).
  • 2 TBSP egg whites
Roll into 12 meatballs and place on a cookie sheet lined with a Silpat Non-Stick Baking Mat.
Cut 6 green pimiento stuffed olives in half and insert them deeply into the top of each meatball to mimic an iris and pupil.
Place in the oven for 30-35 minutes until cooked through

Nutritional Information: (For 1 Turkey Meatball):

calories: 44, fat: 1.9 g, saturated fat: 0.5 g, cholesterol: 21.4 mg, sodium: 37.7 mg, carbohydrates: 0.7 g, fiber: 0.2 g, sugars: 0.2 g, protein: 6.3 g

Watch the video & tell me what you think of my Halloween Costume!

posts.title: Ingredient Encyclopedia
posts.content:
A

Agave Nectar

  • Agave nectar is a commercially produced sweetener known to be considerably sweeter than sugar.  It is produced from the Blue Agave, which is a large spiky plant that resembles a cactus and thrives in the volcanic soils of Southern Mexico.
  • One cup of agave nectar contains roughly the same amount of calories as a cup of sugar. Agave nectar, however, is considerably sweeter than sugar, which is why you can use considerably less portions of it to achieve the desired sweetness. In fact, you can use 1/3 of a cup of agave in place of 1 cup of sugar in your dessert recipes, which will dramatically reduce your caloric intake.
  • It’s gluten-free and has a low glycemic index because it’s mostly comprised of fructose. However, many brands of agave nectar contain fructose levels ranging from 70-97%, which is why it is being declared as “worse than high-fructose corn syrup,” which contains 55% fructose. In fact, agave nectar has the highest fructose content of any commercial sweetener (including sugar, which has 50% fructose) because it is being over-processed. Consuming large quantities of fructose increases your risk of heart disease, obesity and type 2 diabetes.
  • If you do your homework, you will find agave nectars on the market that are processed below 118 degrees F, contain no artificial fillers, contain less than 50% fructose and have a low glycemic index. An example of one such product is Volcanic Nectars Blue Agave Nectar. But remember that Volcanic Nectar Agave is still a sugar and needs to be consumed in moderation.
  • For more information, please read my article, Agave Nectar: Sweet or Dangerous.

All-Natural Crunchy Peanut Butter

  • Unlike regular peanut butter, all natural peanut butter does not contain hydrogenated fats, trans fats, sugar or salt.  It is made solely with peanuts!
  • A freshly opened jar contains a layer of oil on top: store the jar upside down in your pantry to keep the oil at the bottom.
  • Stir to blend the oil with the rest of the butter before serving.

Almond Flour:

  • Almond flour/meal is ground from whole, blanched sweet almonds.
  • Adding almond meal to your baking brings the health benefits of almonds to your diet
  • It’s low carb
  • It’s gluten free
  • Store it in the fridge or freezer.
  • Use it for baking (pie crusts, cakes, cookies, pancakes, quick breads) and for cooking (use it instead of bread crumbs).

Apple Cider Vinegar:

  • Crushing apples makes apple cider vinegar. The resulting liquid is combined with bacteria and yeast to initiate the alcohol fermentation process. Sugars are converted into alcohol, which then undergoes further fermentation and is converted into vinegar by acetic acid-forming bacteria. The main ingredient in apple cider vinegar is acetic acid, which is responsible for its bitter taste. It also contains vitamins, minerals and amino acids. Did you know it is also provides a source of phosphorus, calcium, sodium, potassium, iron, magnesium, chlorine and B-vitamins? Perhaps you have used this ancient folk remedy as a salad dressing. With recent studies suggesting apple cider vinegar could help with several conditions including diabetes and obesity, it has gained popularity and is even being sold as pills.  Although the findings sound promising, more studies will need to be conducted on apple cider vinegar to establish if it actually does offer any health benefits.
  • You may have noticed apple cider vinegar in the weight loss supplement aisle.  Vinegar has been purported to enable weight loss for thousands of years.  One possible theory is that it prolongs the sensation of satiety after eating.  A 2009 study on mice showed that acetic acid (the main ingredient in apple cider vinegar) increases the rate of gene expression for fatty acid oxidation enzymes in the liver, which suppresses body fat accumulation.  Other theories suggest that apple cider vinegar prevents weight gain by facilitating digestion, increasing the rate of gastric emptying and aiding in energy release. At the current time, there is no conclusive evidence supporting the claim that apple cider vinegar is effective for weight reduction or maintenance.
  • What is the recommended dosage? There are no official recommendations. Commonly used dosages include:
    • Two teaspoons a day (mixed in a cup of water).
    • One 285 mg tablet.

    Apple cider vinegar tablets are not regulated by the FDA, which means the vinegar content can vary dramatically from brand to brand.

  • Are there any risks? The risks associated with occasional intake of small quantities of apple cider vinegar are low. However, long-term intake of apple cider vinegar in high dosages is associated with the following risks:
    • Lowered potassium levels.
    • Lowered bone density (osteoporosis)
    • Altered insulin levels (apple cider vinegar contains chromium which can alter insulin levels. Diabetics should consult with their physician before using apple cider vinegar).
    • Pure apple cider vinegar is highly acidic (its main ingredient is acetic acid) and can damage tooth enamel and burn the tissues in your mouth, throat and esophagus. Always dilute it with water before consuming it. One website recommended you should scrub your teeth with apple cider vinegar to break up stains on your teeth. DO NOT do this unless you want to erode away your tooth enamel!
    • Drug interactions: Apple cider vinegar may interact with medications such as diuretics, laxatives, and medications for diabetes and heart disease.
  • Should we be consuming apple cider vinegar? Consuming it as a salad dressing should be fine. Taking it as a daily medical treatment may be risky. At the present time there is not enough evidence indicating that apple cider vinegar has any health benefit for any condition. Always consult with your physician. Always dilute it with water before consuming it (2 teaspoons a day mixed in a cup of water).  I enjoy consuming it as a salad dressing.

Coconut Oil: (Extra Virgin)

  • Coconut oil, known for its high levels of saturated fat, has a reputation for years for raising cholesterol and increasing your risk of heart disease. This theory; however, is now being revisited. Is coconut oil the exception? Is coconut oil a healthy saturated fat?
  • Coconut oil, which is popular amongst vegans, is a vegetable fat that is solid at room temperature. It has a sweet coconut flavour, which makes it a great ingredient for baked goods and sautés1. I use it in my skillet to sauté my chicken, shrimp, scallops, and egg-white omelets, to roast my sweet potatoes in the oven, and to make chocolate protein powder fudge! You can even use it in your smoothies, on your salads or on your popcorn.
  • It is heat stable, which is why it is well suited for cooking food at high temperatures1. In fact, it is the only oil that is stable enough to resist heat-induced damage.2 Frying oxidizes oils such as extra virgin olive oil and canola oil2. Vegetable oils such as corn oil, sunflower oil and canola oil are omega-6 vegetable oils. Not only do they contribute to the undesirable imbalance of the omega-6 to 3 ratio, but they also generate toxic chemicals when fried2.
  • From where does coconut oil’s stigma arise? Apparently studies involving coconut oil were performed using partially hydrogenated coconut oil1. As we know, partial hydrogenation generates dangerous trans fats while destroying many essential fatty acids and antioxidants naturally present in the virgin coconut oil1. Extra virgin coconut oil, however, is not chemically treated. Furthermore, not all saturated fats are villains. In fact, medium chain fatty acids, which are found in coconut oil mainly as lauric acid, are linked to increased levels of HDL “good” cholesterol1 and other health benefits such as increased thermogenesis, weight loss and immunity2. Unlike long chain fatty acids which are predominantly stored as fat, medium chain fatty acids are thought to be health-promoting because they are sent directly to the liver to be burned for energy rather than being stored as fat2. At this time, there is no concrete scientific evidence supporting the health benefits of coconut oil1.
  • Nevertheless, a dentist named Dr. Weston Price examined traditional diets in the South Pacific in the 1930s and their effect on dental and total body health. His findings revealed that those who ate diets high in coconut products were lean and healthy.2 Similarly, a 1981 study published in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition on the effects of a coconut-based diet among 2 Polynesian populations demonstrated positive vascular health in both groups.
  • Conclusion: Although coconut oil is 90% saturated fat, it has been established that not all saturated fat is created equal. Always consult with your physician before adding extra virgin coconut oil to your diet.
