posts.title: Pumpkin Protein Cake
posts.content:
I needed to use my leftover canned pumpkin before it went bad. Hence Pumpkin Protein Cake! I love how this unplanned recipe ended up becoming a delicious masterpiece!

You’ll never guess what I used for the stem. A Quest Bar!

This cake is so good! Like OMG & oh la la la. Plus it’s

  • high in protein
  • low net carb
  • high in fibre
  • very low in sugar
  • loaded with healthy fat
  • gluten free

Cake Recipe:

Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F.

Combine the following ingredients into a bowl and mix:

  • 1/4 cup Almond Flour
  • 1/4 cup Ground Flaxseed Meal
  • 3/4 Scoop BSN Syntha-6 Whey (Cinnamon Bun)
  • 10 drops of vanilla cupcake Capella flavour drops (to make the cake sweeter) – or you can use vanilla extract or vanilla stevia.
  • 1 Egg
  • 1/4 cup Egg Whites
  • 1 cup pumpkin (this makes the cake moist… if you omit this, it will be DRY).
  • 1/4 cup unsweetened almond milk (vanilla)
  • add last:
    • 1/2 tsp baking soda
    • 1/2 tsp baking powder

Place this mixture (which may seem runny, but that’s ok because you don’t want a dry cake) into greased 6″ x 2&3/4″ springform pan (I used PAM).

Bake in the oven at 350 degrees F for 40-45 minutes (use a toothpick to verify the cake is cooked).

Cool before removing the springform casing. Apply icing after the cake has cooled.

Icing Recipe:

Add the following to a bowl and mix to create the icing:

  • 1/4 cup (4 TBSP) pumpkin (this makes the icing orange!)
  • 3/4 scoop BSN Syntha-6 Whey (Cinnamon Bun)
  • 1 TBSP Walden Farms Calorie Free Pancake Syrup. You can use vanilla extract or vanilla stevia if you prefer to sweeten the icing.

Edible Leaves & Stem Decoration:

  • I used 2 spinach leaves to decorate the top of the cake
  • 1 used 1/2 of a Chocolate Peanut Butter Quest Bar. I placed it in the microwave for 10 seconds so I could roll it into a cylinder shape like a stem. Then I pushed it into the centre of the cake.

Nutritional Info:

This recipe yields 8 pieces of cake. Place leftover pieces into the fridge.

For 1/8 of the cake WITH icing:

  • 96.5calories, 4.6g fat, 0.7g saturated fat, 36.6mg cholesterol, 137.85mg sodium, carb: 7.5g, fiber: 3.9g, NET CARBS: 3.6g, sugars:1.8g, protein: 7.8g

For 1/2 of a chocolate peanut butter Quest Bar:

  • 80 calories, 2.5g fat, saturated fat: 0.5g, cholesterol2.5mg, sodium: 135mg, carb: 12.5g, fiber:8.5g, sugar alcohol: 2.5g, NET CARBS: 1.5g, sugars:0.5g, protein: 10g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

posts.title: Cheesy Protein Bread (Low Carb)
posts.content:
OMG! Why didn’t I concoct this recipe ages ago? Cheesy Bread: Where have you been all my life?

DISCLAIMER: Have you ever eaten something so good that you have to stand up and do a little jig whilst simultaneously humming and chewing? Yep, this happens if you eat this cheesy bread.

REJOICE because my cheesy bread is:

  • Loaded with protein and healthy fat
  • Rife with fiber
  • Virtually sugar free
  • Low carb (only 1.2g net carbs per slice) – perfect for diabetics or people who want to be as thin as a bat’s ear.
  • Dairy free
  • And there’s no wheat flour in my cheesy bread! That means you don’t have to worry about the refined-flour energy spike. No siree bob! I use low carb almond and coconut flour instead! BAM, POW & SLAM!

Feast your eyes on this warm, delicious, crunchy cheesy bread:

Easy Recipe:

Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F

Combine and mix the following ingredients into a bowl:

  • 1/4 cup Almond Flour
  • 1 TBSP Coconut Flour
  • 1 TBSP Ground Flaxseed Meal
  • 1 TBSP Whole Flaxseeds (to create a “multigrain crunchy effect”)
  • 2 TBSP Nutritional Yeast Flakes
  • 2 TBSP GG Bran Fiber Sprinkles (to create a “multigrain crunchy effect”)
  • 1/4 cup unsweetened almond milk (unflavoured)
  • 1/2 cup egg whites

Place this mixture into a small loaf pan (4″ x 6″). I coated the pan with non-stick cooking spray (PAM).

Bake in the oven at 350 degrees F for 40-45 minutes (use a toothpick to verify the loaf is cooked).

Cool and remove from the pan. Slice into 5 pieces.

Nutritional Information:

For the entire loaf:

calories: 385, total fat: 20.1g, saturated fat: 2.6 g, cholesterol: 0, sodium: 282.5mg, carbohydrates: 22.2g, fiber: 16.1g, NET CARBS: 6.1 g, sugars: 1.5g, protein: 30.4g

For 1 slice (1/5 of loaf):

calories: 77, total fat: 4g, saturated fat: 0.5 g, cholesterol: 0, sodium: 56.5mg, carbohydrates: 4.4g, fiber: 3.2g, NET CARBS: 1.2 g, sugars: 0.3g, protein: 6.1g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Quick & Easy Low Carb Appetizers
posts.content:
I wanted to share with you my favourite quick and easy appetizer: Bruschetta on High Fiber Crispbread and Colourful Bell Peppers with Spicy Guacamole.

I like to fill up on both of these high fiber, low carb, low calorie snacks, not only because they taste great, but also because they are very filling. A filling appetizer prevents me from mindlessly eating an entire bag of high calorie cashews before my main course.

This is an ideal appetizer because it obeys The Principle of Volumetrics.

 The Principle of Volumetrics:

  • Eating low-calorie foods (eg. vegetables) makes you feel full and thereby aids in weight loss.
  • Since these foods are high in fiber and water, you can eat generous portions without feeling deprived or hungry.
  • So go ahead and eat your vegetables!
  • It’s relatively easy to adhere to a volumetrics diet over the long haul because you will never feel deprived.

 

All of this is only 135 Calories and 12g Net Carbs! 

 

Easy Recipe:

To save time, I purchased pre-made bruschetta and guacamole! Work smarter, not harder!

 

 

Bruschetta:

  • Break 2 GG Bran Scandinavian Crispbreads in half.
    • Note: Canadian shoppers can get it here.
    • Note: this crispbread is not gluten free.
  • Divide 2 TBSP of Bruschetta amongst the 4 crispbreads.
    • For all the Canadians reading this, I used President’s Choice Bruschetta from Loblaws. Two tablespoons are only 15 calories, 1 g fat, 1 g carb, and 1 g sugar.

Bell Peppers and Guacamole:

  • Cut 1 cup of bell peppers (any colour). I used white, chocolate, purple, green and orange peppers.
  • Measure 2 TBSP of Spicy Wholly Guacamole into a dish. This brand of guacamole gets my seal of approval: It’s made with avocado and is free of chemicals and preservatives.
    • Avocado can help you lose weight: Half an avocado contains ~5 grams of fiber  (soluble and insoluble: which keeps your digestive system running smoothly). Furthermore, soluble fibre slows the breakdown of carbohydrates in your body, helping you feel full for longer

Nutritional Information for both snacks:

calories: 135, fat: 7.4g, saturated fat: 1g, cholesterol: 0mg, sodium: 256mg, carbohydrates: 27g, fiber: 15.1g, NET CARBS: 11.9g sugars: 7.3g, protein: 5.5g

Also Recommended:

  1. To learn more about Fiber, GG Bran Crispbread and Net carbs, read my article called, “Fiber Facts and Net Carbs“.
  2. Two other high fiber, low carb healthy snacks I recommend include:
    1. Quest Nutrition Bars
    2. Quest Nutrition’s Protein Peanut Butter Cups
  3. For more low carb snack ideas, read my article, “13 Best Low Carb Portable Snacks”

posts.title: Chocolate Peanut Butter Bites!
posts.content:
The combination of chocolate and peanut butter is hard to beat. This high-protein, low-carb, fiber-packed snack is so good, you’ll feel like you’re cheating on your diet!

Recipe:

Ingredients:

  • 1 scoop BSN ISOBURN whey (chocolate milkshake)
  • 1 TBSP ground flax seed meal
  • 2.5 TBSP All Natural Crunchy peanut butter

How to Prepare: Thoroughly mix all the ingredients in a bowl (add a little water if necessary; 1 tbsp at a time). Use a tablespoon to form half-spheres (place them into mini silicone baking cups so they won’t stick) and place in freezer for 2 hours before eating (if time is an issue, you can eat them right away, but they taste better when frozen).

Servings: 8

Nutritional Information:

This recipe also yields 8 balls.

The entire recipe is:

  • 225 calories, fat: 10.9g, saturated fat: 1.1g, cholesterol: 10mg, sodium: 170mg, carbohydrates: 9.5g, fiber: 4.8g, NET CARBS: 4.7g, sugars 2.8g, protein 24.8g

One ball (1/8th of the recipe) is:

  • 28 calories, fat: 1.4g, saturated fat: 0.1g, cholesterol: 1.25mg, sodium: 21.25mg, carbohydrates: 1.2g, fiber: 0.6g, NET CARBS: 0.6g, sugars 0.35g, protein 3.1g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients used in this recipe in my Ingredient Encyclopaedia.

Who is Dr. Mike?

Author, speaker, and nutritional consultant Mike Roussell, PhD is known for transforming complex nutritional concepts into practical nutritional habits that his clients can use to ensure permanent weight loss and long lasting health. Dr. Roussell holds a bachelor degree in biochemistry from Hobart College and a doctorate in nutrition from Pennsylvania State University. Dr. Roussell maintains a popular diet and nutrition blog at MikeRoussell.com. Be sure to join Dr. Mike on Facebook and Twitter!

I had the pleasure of meeting Dr. Mike at the 2012 Bodybuilding.com Holiday Party. It turns out that Dr. Mike has been writing articles for Bodybuilding.com since 2005!

Life is about the people you meet. I’m truly blessed to be a Team Bodybuilding.com Athlete, as this has provided me with an opportunity to meet some of the brightest minds in this industry. Thank you Dr. Mike for letting me pick your brain about everything from intermittent fasting and ketogenic diets to Splenda and stevia controversies! When I told Dr. Mike I love to write recipes, he told me about a recipe he recently concocted. And guess what??!! He offered to let me share it on my Blog! Now how awesome is that?

posts.title: Eggcellent Stuffed Chocolate Peppers
posts.content:
Chocolate Pepper?

chocolate and purple peppers

When I saw chocolate peppers in the grocery store, I became very excited. I had never seen a chocolate pepper before! At first I wondered, do they taste like chocolate? Or are they merely named after their chocolate brown colouring? I google searched them, and this is what I uncovered:

  • They are bell peppers that ripen from green to brown if left to mature for 85 days
  • As they change colour, the sweetness increases.
  • The don’t taste like chocolate (boooo!). They are much sweeter than green peppers, but not as sweet as red peppers.

I also decided to buy a dark purple pepper (because I have never tried this either)!

  • I was shocked when I cut into the purple pepper, and uncovered green flesh!
  • A pigment called anthocyanin produces the dark purple color. It also contains antioxidant properties.
  • It has a sweet green flavour and a crisp texture. It’s not as sweet as a red pepper.
  • And we all know that Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers.

purple pepper

Did you know? Red peppers are simply ripened green peppers!

Eggcellent Stuffed Chocolate Pepper

  • Cut the lid (top) off of a pepper (any colour will do). Chop up the lid and use it later for the egg white scramble. Remove and discard the seed core from the inside.
  •  Place the following into a non-stick skillet (or use non-stick cooking spray, such as PAM):
    • The extra saved pepper pieces
    • 1 cup spinach (I buy mine pre-washed & cut to save time)
    • 1 cup of egg whites
    • 4 sliced cherry tomatoes
    • 1/2 cup mushrooms
    • 1/4 cup Daiya Vegan Cheese Mozzarella Style Shreds
      • Daiya Vegan Cheese, which is free of dairy (casein, whey and lactose), soy, gluten, eggs, rice, peanuts and tree nuts (except coconut oil).  It is also cholesterol & trans-fat free and contains no preservatives.  You can find it in the cheese section of your grocery store.
      • I use vegan cheese because dairy gives me dairyarrhea.
    • Season with Black Pepper and Salt-Free Seasoning (eg. Mrs. Dash)
  • Place the egg mixture into the pepper bowl. Enjoy!

Nutritional Information:

calories: 218, fat: 2.2g, saturated fat: 0.6g, cholesterol: 0mg, sodium: 510.1mg, carbohydrates: 16g, fiber: 4.9g, NET CARBS: 11.1g, sugars: 8.7g, protein: 32.2g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients used in this recipe in my Ingredient Encyclopaedia.

posts.title: Smoked Salmon Pâté with Low Carb Crackers
posts.title_plain: Smoked Salmon Pâté with Low Carb Crackers
posts.content:
You probably wouldn’t have known I was a Canadian Jew if my last name weren’t Solomon, eh? Ok, maybe the Jew-Fro in my baby picture is a giveaway.

 

In celebration of Passover (Pesach), which is March 25-April 2, 2013, I decided to make a healthy version of this traditional Jewish staple: a bagel with lox and cream cheese (a.k.a “The Jew Burger”). My healthy version of this fat-storing delicacy is Smoked Salmon Pâté with Low Carb Crackers:
Jews love traditions:
  • Lox and bagels
  • Going to summer camp (Although, for whatever reason, my parents sent me and my sister to Bible Camp. We were the only 2 Jews there.)
  • Hebrew school (Much to my grandmother’s chagrin, my sister and I were Hebrew school dropouts. We can’t speak a lick of Hebrew, but at least we know all the words to Christian hymns)
  • Shopping
  • Going to Florida
  • Becoming doctors and dentists. (Did I mention my sister is a dermatologist and I’m a dentist?)

As a young child, I recall chowing down on lox quite frequently. But then one magical day my taste buds stumbled upon “smushed lox” at one of our family rejewnions. OMG I loved it!

  • Smushed lox is just lox that has been puréed with cream cheese. You can spread it on your matzah, melba toast, Montreal bagels, or whatever.
  • I suspect it was brought to the reunion to accommodate the edentulous relatives, but who cares because it’s YUMMY!

Lox vx. Smoked Salmon:

There is a difference! Lox refers to the midsection of a salmon that’s been cured in a salt brine. That explains why lox has a saltier flavour than smoked salmon. For today’s recipe, I’m using smoked salmon, because that’s all I had in my freezer.

Quick & Easy Recipe:

This dairy free pâté recipe is EASY: you only need 4 ingredients and 4 minutes to make it! Plus, it’s Low Carb! Perfect for diabetics or anyone following a Low Carbohatred Diet!

Combine and purée the following in a food processor:

  • 1 TBSP Toffuti Vegan Cream Cheese. If you prefer to use a non-soy option that is also dairy free, then use Daiya Dairy Free Cream Cheese Spread or even guacamole. If you do not have an allergy to dairy, then feel free to use light cream cheese or low fat cottage cheese.
  • 3 oz Smoked Salmon
  • 1/2 TBSP lemon juice
  • Dill (fresh is ideal). I only had Dill Weed in my pantry, which still got the job done.

Spread the pâté over 2 GG Bran Scandinavian Crispbreads.

  • This crispbread is from Norway, and is prepared from 85% unprocessed bran, with rye flour and water. When you eat GG Scandinavian Bran Crispbread, it quickly absorbs more moisture and satisfies your appetite.  It boasts the lowest in calories (12 calories a slice) and net carbs (2 g per slice)  of any bread product on the market. Note: it is NOT gluten free!
    • What are net carbs? Read my article “Fiber Facts and Net Carbs” to find out!

Nutritional Information:

calories: 226, fat: 11.7g, saturated Fat: 2.5g, cholesterol: 77.3mg, sodium: 707.1mg, carbohydrates: 17.2g, fiber: 10g, NET CARBS: 7.2g, sugars: 0.2g, protein: 22.6g

Vegan Cream Cheese:

Vegan cream cheese is the non-dairy substitute for cream cheese. It is similar in taste and texture to traditional cream cheese, but it is milk and butterfat free and contains no cholesterol. It is made from soy protein, tofu, and does not contain any hydrogenated oils. It is vegan, kosher certified and gluten-free.  The only disadvantage is that it does contain some thickeners which are corn-derived (maltodextrin). I recommend using it as a cream cheese substitute, for cream cheese frosting and dairy-free cheesecakes.  One tablespoon only has 30 calories, 2.5g fat, 1 g carbohydrates, no sugar and 0.5g protein. You can find it in the refrigerator section of your natural grocer.

Soy What!  

Yes, there is tremendous controversy and paranoia surrounding soy.  Let’s put an end to the soyspicions by debunking the soy myths with the help of some experts:

  • Dr. Andrew Weil, MD:  click for his take on soy
  • Dr. Mark Hyman’s discussion about soy on the Dr. Oz show: click for his take
  • Chocolate Covered Katie, The Internet Queen of Vegan Desserts: click for her take
  • The Effects of Soy on Health Outcomes: This report is from the Agency for HealthCare Research and Quality reviewed thousands of studies about soy
  • A Brief Historical Overview of the Past Two Decades of Soy and Isoflavone Research–Published in the The Journal of Nutrition.

Yes, I Eat Soy in Moderation! You can do whatever you like! Just remember: Everything in moderation.  Even moderation in moderation!

Smoked Salmon Safety Facts:

  • Smoked salmon has a high nutrient content; however, its high levels of sodium make it a delicacy that should be eaten in moderation and avoided by those with heart conditions.
  • A 4 ounce serving of smoked salmon contains no sugar and 27 g of high-quality protein.
  • It contains high amounts of heart-healthy omega-3 fatty acids, which are known to reduce your risk of heart disease.
  • Smoked salmon has less omega-3’s than non-smoked salmon
  • One serving of smoked salmon contains 71% of your recommended daily intake of vitamin B12, 44% of vitamin B1 (niacin), 32% of vitamin B6, and 31% of phosphorus.
  • Wild Alaskan smoked salmon has the lowest contamination risk (negligible mercury levels).
  • Because the salmon is smoked, it may contain toxic substances called polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), which are known to increase the risk of cancer.
  • High heat smoking creates more undesirable PAHs.
  • Cold-smoked salmon (70-100F for at least 12 hours) contain less PAHs, but is typically preserved with carcinogenic nitrates or nitrites for a longer shelf-life.
  • Smoked salmon is not as healthy as fresh or canned salmon.  Nevertheless, most people who are in good health are able to benefit from smoked salmon because they have healthy detoxification systems that can process and eliminate the PAHs or preservatives found in smoked fish.
  • References:
    • http://whfoods.org/genpage.php?tname=dailytip&dbid=320’
    • http://www.livestrong.com/article/377233-is-smoked-salmon-healthy/

posts.title: Chocolate Soft Serve (with a secret ingredient)
posts.title_plain: Chocolate Soft Serve (with a secret ingredient)
posts.content:
• Presenting Chocolate Soft Serve … with a secret ingredient. Shhh! It’s like a government secret

You’ll have to keep reading to learn what the secret ingredient is…

This heavenly dessert won’t sabotage your physique!

It’s made with ingredients from Bodybuilding.com, which is why it’s very high in protein and low in sugar.

  • BSN Syntha-6 Whey (flavour =  Chocolate Cake Batter)
  • Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free Pancake Syrup 

Guess what the secret ingredient is???? ZUCCHINI!

  • I swear you cannot taste the zucchini in the ice cream.
  • The zucchini is the reason why the soft serve is so creamy!
  • Shhhh! don’t tell the kids there is a zucchini in their dessert.

5-Ingredient Recipe:

Add the following to a magic bullet cup (or a blender):

  • 2/3 scoop BSN Syntha-6 Whey (flavour = Chocolate Cake Batter)
  • 1/2 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk
  • 2 TBSP Walden Farms Sugar Free/Calorie Free Pancake Syrup  (to sweeten it)
  • Peel the skin off a zucchini. Add 1 cup of chopped raw zucchini.
  • Mix these 3 ingredients together in a Magic Bullet. Ensure the zucchini is completely pureed.

Pour the mixture into an ice cream machine for 15-20 minutes. Watch my “How to Use an Ice Cream Machine Tootorial Video” or just read my instructions here.

  • Serve in a bowl and drizzle with 1 TBSP Walden Farms Sugar Free/Calorie Free Pancake Syrup 
  • I was feeling fancy, and sprinkled 1 TBSP of chocolate PB2  (powdered peanut butter) on top of my soft serve. It was a delicious addition.

Nutritional Information:

Note: this includes the pancake syrup and chocolate PB2:

calories: 203, fat: 6.9g, saturated fat: 1.6g, cholesterol: 36.6mg, sodium: 348.2mg, carbohydrates: 18.8g, dietary fiber: 6.1g, NET CARBS: 12.7g, sugars: 8.2g, protein: 19.2g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

posts.title: Chicken Taco Salad in a Low Carb Edible Bowl
posts.title_plain: Chicken Taco Salad in a Low Carb Edible Bowl
posts.content:
I just created a healthy version of  Taco Bell’s Fiesta Taco Chicken Salad!

Taco Bell’s Fiesta Taco Salad – Chicken:

calories: 730 (YIKES), fat: 35g (YIKES), saturated fat: 7g, cholesterol: 70mg, sodium: 1290mg (YIKES), carbohydrates 71g (YIKES), fiber: 8g, sugars: 8 g, protein: 32g

Sara’s Healthy Fiesta Taco Salad – Chicken:

“A portobello mushroom cap (“bowl”) filled with extra lean ground chicken, and loaded with vegan mozeralla cheese, diced ripe cherry tomatoes, mushrooms, yellow peppers and cucumbers, topped with spicy guacamole”.

Even one of the gigantic mushroom caps won’t add significantly to your daily calorie intake. So have two! Besides, portobello mushrooms provide you with copper, folate, niacin, potassium and calcium!14  And did you know portobello mushrooms are just crimini mushrooms grown to a large size?

Nutritional Info:

for 2 bowls:

calories: 291, fat: 15.7g, saturated fat: 9g, cholesterol: 64.1mg, sodium: 287.8mg, carbohydrates 21.4mg, fiber: 10g, NET CARBS: 11.4 g, sugars: 2.7 g, protein: 28.5g

Easy Recipe:

  • Wash and dry 2 large portobello mushroom caps. Tear/cut off the stalks and use a spoon to scoop out a portion of the inside of the mushroom cap (to create a deeper bowl).
  • Place the 2 caps (and all the extra pieces of the mushroom you removed) onto a non-stick skillet (or use non-stick cooking spray). Flip the caps to grill them on both sides.
  • In another skillet (use non-stick cooking spray), cook extra lean ground chicken. Season it with black pepper.
  • Wash and cut 4 cherry tomatoes, 1/2 cup cucumber and 1/2 cup of yellow pepper
  • Once the chicken and caps are finished, measure 3 oz of chicken and place 1.5 oz into each mushroom bowl. Top the chicken in each bowl with
  • The leftover mushroom pieces
  • The cherry tomatoes, cucumber and yellow peppers
  • 1/8 cup Daiya Vegan Cheese Mozzarella Style Shreds (1/16 cup for each bowl). You can use skim cheese if you have no dairy allergy.
    • Daiya Vegan Cheese, which is free of dairy (casein, whey and lactose), soy, gluten, eggs, rice, peanuts and tree nuts (except coconut oil).  It is also cholesterol & trans-fat free and contains no preservatives.  You can find it in the cheese section of your grocery store.
  • 1 TBSP of Spicy Wholly Guacamole on each bowl. (You can purchase it at your grocery store).
  • 1 tsp of Salsa or Guacamole Seasoning on each bowl.
  • Season with Black Pepper

*REMEMBER: Your health is your freedom. Without it, you have nothing. It’s time to start defending your health and the health of your children.

This recipe is also posted on Steven J. Wong’s fabulous website anti-agem.com. In the post on his website, I also shed insight into childhood obesity. It’s up to us to empower our children to make better dietary choices. Let’s start by showing them healthier ways to make their favourite fast food dishes. And we all know no one takes the “hell out of healthy” like Dr. Sara Solomon does! You can access it by clicking here.

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

posts.title: Pan-Seared Scallops on a Bed of Zucchini Noodles
posts.title_plain: Pan-Seared Scallops on a Bed of Zucchini Noodles
posts.content:
Zucchini Noodles (aka ” low carb faux pasta noodles”) are the best thing since indoor plumbing, the number 36, electric toothbrushes, vegetarian steakhouses, Klingon, the internet, the word “booyah”, and books that teach you how to read. However, if you can’t read, then you can’t learn from books, so you can’t learn to read by reading a book that tells how to read.

But I digress. Zucchini Noodles actually taste, feel and slurp like pasta noodles.

Easy Recipe:

1. Make & Cook the Zucchini Noodles

  • Wash a medium-sized zucchini, but you don’t have to peel it if you like the green colour in your pasta. Be aware that the peel contains a good portion of the zucchini’s vitamins and minerals, so eat the peel!
  • Place the zucchini in your Spiral Vegetable Slicer (refer to my photo) and turn the crank.
    • If you don’t have a spiral vegetable slicer, I strongly recommend you get one, especially considering they are only ~ $30. Otherwise, you can use a mandolin or a vegetable peeler, neither of which are as quick or as neat-o as the spiral vegetable slicer).

 

 

  • Toss the following onto a non-stick skillet on medium heat (or use non-stick cooking spray) for ~3-5 minutes:
    • 1.5 cups of zucchini noodles
    • 1/2 cup of mushrooms
    • 2 TBSP of Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free Alfredo Sauce

2. Pan-Sear Your Scallops:

  • While your veggies are cooking, start cooking the scallops in another non-stick skillet (or use non-stick cooking spray) over medium-high heat. Cook the scallops until they are deep golden brown on one side (about 1 to 2 minutes on each side). Cooking time will vary depending on the size and thickness of your scallops. Once the scallops and veggies are done, combine them onto a plate. I measured 6 oz of scallops.

3. Garnish with freshly ground black pepper and 1 TBSP of Nutritional Yeast, which will impart a cheesy flavour. It’s dairy free. For more info about nutritional yeast, click here.

Nutritional Information:

calories: 220, fat: 2.5g, saturated fat: 0.2g, cholesterol: 52 mg, sodium: 376.9mg, carbohydrates: 15.2 g, fiber: 3.7 g, NET CARBS: 11.5g, sugars: 8.5 g, protein: 35.3g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Rice Paper Shrimp Rolls
posts.content:
Rice Paper is my latest obsession. Rice paper may not provide much nutritional value, but it is gluten free and very user-friendly. It also offers a low calorie approach to making your clean eats look more like cheats. I bet you get really bored eating shrimp and salad. So why not play tricks on your taste buds by wrapping your shrimp salad into a low-calorie edible wrapper?

Quick & Easy Recipe

This recipe yields 2 rice paper shrimp rolls:

NOTE:

  • Make one roll at a time to prevent a sticky rice paper disaster!
  • Get all of your ingredients ready to go! Once you wet the rice paper, you need to hustle.
  1. Soak a sheet of Rice Paper (click that link for brown rice paper) under warm running tap water for about 15 seconds. Shake to dry it off.
  2. Place the rice paper onto a plate.
  3. Load the rice paper with 2 oz of shrimp, 1/4 cup of enoki mushrooms, 1/4 cup of broccoli slaw (trust me, that’s all that will fit!).
  4. Drizzle 1/2 TBSP of Wholly Spicy Guacamole (available in your grocery store). This is a tasty way to include a healthy fat in this recipe.
  5. Neatly fold the bottom edge of the rice paper over the filling. Then fold in the side edges of the rice paper. Roll up the rice paper roll to form a neatly packed cylinder. I was never particularly good at origami, so I just rolled it up like a sleeping bag. Do whatever works for you!
  6. Repeat steps 1 through 5 for the second roll.

 

Notes:

  • Feel free to use your favourite fresh vegetables. I like to save time by purchasing pre-washed and cut veggies and pre-cooked shrimp. Remember, you will be more capable of enduring and maintaining a healthy diet 365 days a year if you work smarter, not harder in the kitchen.
  • I use enoki mushrooms instead of dried vermicelli noodles or miracle noodles because I want my body to benefit from the nutrients in the mushrooms. Besides, enoki mushrooms look like vermicelli noodles anyway. It’s all about playing tricks on your mind!
  • No, you don’t have to use rice paper. If you want an even lower carb option, then wrap your shrimp and veggies with collard greens.
  • Depending on my mood, I will fill my rice paper wrap with spicy guacamole (which provides a healthy fat) or shrimp sauce. I don’t bother dipping my shrimp rolls in sauce because they are already “saucy” enough, making the extra dipping calories completely unjustifiable. You’ll thank me later when you get to eat an extra Quest Bar from Bodybuilding.com because you selected your calories wisely. If you understand how to make calorie trade-offs, then you will get to eat your favourite foods daily. This is how I manage to stay within my caloric limits without feeling deprived. For example, if I know I want to eat an extra Quest Bar and pig out on some kale chips, then I’ll make little undetectable calorie-reducing changes to all of my other meals, such as using water instead of almond milk, PB2 instead of peanut butter, and I’ll use Walden Farms calorie free sauces from Bodybuilding.com (they even have a calorie free shrimp sauce!)
  • Here is my shrimp sauce version:

Nutritional Information:

For 2 rice paper shrimp rolls (using the spicy guacamole):

calories: 200, fat: 4.4g, saturated fat: 1g, cholesterol: 206.7mg, sodium: 499mg, carbohydrates: 22g, fiber: 2.9g, NET CARBS: 19.1g, sugars: 1.1g, protein: 21 g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

Sara’s Diet Rant: USE YOUR BRAIN!

 

source: http://ilovefunnypics.com/hows-your-diet-going/

I’ve been eating these rice paper shrimp rolls with a Quest Bar for Dessert every day for the past week, and this is what I look like. Yes, I have an 8-pack! This is proof that my MAINTAINABLE AND ENDURABLE approach to eating WORKS! Stop with the unpalatable meal plans of chicken, tilapia, broccoli and asparagus and start using common sense … that is, if you actually want to enjoy your food, experience variety and not feel deprived. Bottom line: you don’t have to deprive yourself, demonize food, starve yourself, or spend hours cooking to have an 8-pack. My secret? Intermittent Fasting & Flexible Dieting!

posts.title: Layered Peanut Butter Cup Fudge
posts.content:
Due to the immense popularity of my Peanut Butter Cookie Protein Fudge, I decided to whip up another protein fudge recipe. And this one is EVEN BETTER!

Presenting Layered Peanut Butter Cup Fudge!

Recipe:

This fudge is no-bake, low carb, virtually sugar-free and high in protein.

Chocolate Layer: Mix by hand or place the following into a Magic Bullet (or a food processor) and blend

  • 1 TBSP of melted Coconut Butter (use microwave)
  • 1/2 scoop of BSN ISOBURN (chocolate milkshake flavour)
  • 2 TBSP unsweetened almond milk (you may need to add ore or less … you want the mixture to be thick)

Line a square or rectangular glass dish (a tupperware container will work too) with plastic wrap. This makes it easy to remove the fudge from the dish for cutting. Place the mixture evenly into the dish and then place it into the freezer for 5 minutes while you prepare the PB cup cookie dough layer

PB Cup Cookie Dough Layer: Mix by hand or place the following into a clean Magic Bullet (or a food processor) and blend

  • 1 TBSP of melted Coconut Butter (use microwave)
  • 3/4 scoop BSN Syntha-6 Whey (Peanut Butter Cookie flavour)
  • 2 TBSP unsweetened almond milk (you may need to add more or less … you want the mixture to be thick)

Cut 1 Quest Protein Peanut Butter Cup into small pieces. Remove the chocolate fudge from the freezer. Spread your PB Cookie Dough Layer on top of the chocolate fudge layer. Place the cut PB cup pieces into the top layer of fudge. To set the fudge, place the dish into the fridge for a few hours (or into the freezer for 15 minutes if you are impatient like I am!). Cut the fudge into small cubes and serve. Store these in the fridge!

Nutritional Info:

For HALF of this recipe, the nutritional info is as follows:

calories: 263, fat: 16.45 g, saturated fat: 10.75g, cholesterol: 31.9 mg, sodium: 196.9 mg, carbohydrates: 13.6g, fiber: 7 g, NET carbs: 6.6g, sugars: 2.5g, protein 19.4g

Ingredient Information: 

==>Find detailed explanations about the ingredients used in this recipe in my Ingredient Encyclopaedia.

posts.title: Canned Tuna Sushi (low carb, low sodium, spicy version)
posts.title_plain: Canned Tuna Sushi (low carb, low sodium, spicy version)
posts.content:
I hate canned tuna. I hate its cat food odour. I hate the way it tastes.

But, I managed to create a recipe that makes me love canned tuna! Yep! I fooled my taste buds and tricked my brain into thinking it was so much more than just canned tuna.

Presenting CANNED TUNA SUSHI (low carb, low-sodium, spicy version):

10-minute Easy Recipe:

Mix by hand (or use a mini food processor or a magic bullet):

  • 1 can of Raincoast Trading White Solid Albacore Tuna (No Salt added)
    • 1 can has 33.8 mg of sodium
  • 1 TBSP of All-Natural Spicy Wholly Guacamole (available at your grocery store)
  • Seasoning: I used chilli pepper flakes, salt-free Mrs. Dash and a pinch of wasabi powder

 

 

Take 1 Nori Sheet and cut it into 10 strips using scissors. It’s easier to cut it now (cutting it after the tuna is placed makes a squishy mess).

  • Dampen both ends of a nori strip before placing the tuna at one end. Then roll it like a sleeping bag. Moisten the end to get it to stick down. Repeat for the other 9 strips.
  • Place a dollop of the All-Natural Spicy Wholly Guacamole on top of each maki. This represents 1 more TBSP of guacamole.

ENJOY!

*note: I skip the soy sauce.  1 TBSP of soy sauce has about 1000mg of sodium!  So either use low sodium soy sauce, a soy sauce alternative or nothing!

Nutritional Info:

Yields 10 maki:

calories: 263, fat: 12.8g, saturated fat: 3.3g, cholesterol: 67.6mg, sodium: 137.5mg, carbohydrates: 4.5g, fiber: 2.1g, NET CARBS: 2.4g, sugars: 0.1g, protein: 40.9g

Discussion: Tuna & Mercury

Canned tuna is a convenient, inexpensive and portable source of protein.

Rumours swirl that mercury in canned tuna fish makes it a dangerous protein source. Get the facts by reading my article published on Bodybuilding.com called, “The Mercury in Fish Scare – How Safe is All That Seafood You’re Eating?”. To summarize the Canned Tuna section of this article:

  • Tuna mercury levels vary depending upon the type of tuna and where it was caught.
  • Tuna steaks and canned albacore tuna generally contain higher levels of mercury than canned light tuna.
  • “light” tuna refers to any one of the following types of tuna: skipjack, bluefin, yellowfin or tongol. Skipjack is the best choice among these light tuna options for lowering your risk of mercury exposure.
  • Canned tuna packed in water contains a higher omega-3 fat content than oil-packed tuna
  • Although more expensive, specialty brands of canned tuna (such as the Raincoast Trading Brand) offer more omega-3 fatty acids, more sustainable fishing methods and higher-quality production methods.

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

posts.title: Peanut Butter Cookie Fudge
posts.content:
This is officially the most amazingly delicious recipe EVER! Guaranteed to give you a bellygasm.

My parents are visiting so I shared it with them, and they gobbled it up in seconds. Just look at it!

Anyone can make this recipe, even if you are bereft of culinary knowledge. It’s EASY!

  • Ready to eat in 10 minutes
  • 3-ingredients
  • NO BAKE
  • Low carb, virtually sugar-free (diabetes-friendly)
  • High in protein

Recipe:

Place the following into a Magic Bullet (or a food processor) and blend

  • 2 TBSP of melted Coconut Butter (use microwave)
    • Coconut butter is freshly made from whole coconut flesh (not just the oil) and puree’d into a fiberous, densely nutritious & creamy spread.
    • You can use it as a dairy butter substitute in recipes.
    • It hardens when you place it in the fridge/freezer
    • It imparts a rich and creamy texture to the fudge. 
  • 1 scoop BSN Syntha-6 Peanut Butter Cookie Whey
  • If necessary, add 1 to 2 TBSP unsweetened almond milk (or water). You want it to be thick, so don’t add too much liquid. If you can avoid adding liquid, even better!

Line a square or rectangular glass dish (a tupperware container will work too) with plastic wrap (see my photo above). This makes it easy to remove the fudge from the dish for cutting.

Place the mixture evenly into the dish … or you can eat it as frosting!

To make fudge, place the dish into the fridge for a few hours (or into the freezer for 5 to 20 minutes if you are impatient like I am!)

Cut the fudge into small cubes and serve. Store these in the fridge! A single serving represents half of the recipe.

Nutritional Information:

For 1/2 of the recipe, the nutritional info (including  the almond milk) is as follows:

  • calories: 196, fat: 12.2 g, saturated fat: 8.8g, cholesterol: 37.5 mg, sodium: 103.8mg, carbohydrates: 11.6g, fiber: 5.6 g, NET carbs: 6g, sugars: 2g, protein 12.1g

I eat 1/2 of this recipe and place the other half in the fridge for another day. It stores quite nicely in the fridge for up to 4 days!

posts.title: Mint Chocolate Chip Protein Ice
posts.content:
Are you tired of eating spinach and sucking back casein protein shakes?

Me too! That’s why I invented a recipe that masks the sketchy flavours and textures of spinach & casein. Yes! You’re welcome!

Would you believe me if I told you I used casein & spinach to make the best ice cream flavour in the whole world?

Yes! I made mint chocolate chip protein ice cream that tastes exactly like you remember it as a kid! Ridiculously delicious!

My healthy version is PERFECT for bodybuilders, fitness enthusiasts and health conscious folks.

Spinach!

Shhh! Don’t tell people about the spinach because they will have no clue it’s in their ice cream. You cannot taste the spinach at all. It does, however, turn the ice cream a perfect minty shade of green… and without having to use sketchy food colouring.

And let’s not forget that spinach is high in calcium, folic acid, potassium, iron, magnesium, vitamins A & C and lutein.

Easy Recipe:

ingredients

1. Place the following into a mini food processor and blend until it looks like the photo below:

  • 1/4 cup of spinach leaves (remove the stems)
  • 20 mint leaves (remove the stems)
  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk
  • 1/4 tsp guar gum (to make it creamy) – OPTIONAL
  • 1/4 tsp xanthan gum (to thicken it) – OPTIONAL
  • 1 scoop of Bodybuilding.com 100% Casein – Vanilla
  • 1/2 tsp peppermint extract
  • 1/4 tsp vanilla extract

2. Pour this mixture into big measuring cup (with a spout) containing 1/4 cup of water (I added the extra water to yield a greater quantity of ice cream, because I like big portions!)

3.  MAKE THE ICE CREAM:

Step 1: Buy an Ice Cream Machine. I got mine at the rainforest place for ~$50 here. Best thing money can buy. I use mine ALL the time except when I don’t use it.

Step 2: Watch my “How to Use an Ice Cream Machine Tootorial Video” or just read my instructions here.

Pour the mixture into an ice cream machine and set the timer for 15 minutes. Then add 1 tsp (~5g) of raw cacao nibs. Set the timer for 5 more minutes and then serve!

Nutritional Information:

calories: 229, fat: 8.5g, saturated fat: 1.2 g, cholesterol: 15mg, sodium: 371.7mg, carbohydrates: 14.1g, fiber: 5.4 g, NET CARBS: 8.7g, sugars: 2.7g, protein: 26.4g

Compare this to mint chocolate chip ice cream from Baskin Robbins, which has twice the fat, 8 times the saturated fat, 3 times the carbs, 10 times more sugar and 1/5 the amount of protein.

Ingredient Information:

==> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients used in this recipe in my Ingredient Encyclopaedia.

posts.title: Steamed Sole & Vegetables
posts.content:
Full Steam Ahead!

Steaming is one of the fastest ways to prepare vegetables, and with multiple tiers, you can cook an entire meal simultaneously (fish, rice, eggs, vegetables, etc).  Compared to other methods of cooking, steaming is the best method for retaining the vitamin and mineral content of vegetables.

 

My sister gave me a Digital Steamer for my birthday, and I LOVE it because

  • I just fill it up with water and set the timer.
  • It has 3 tiers and a rice bowl (so I can cook enough food for an army)
  • It’s quick! My meal was done in 18 minutes! And I didn’t have to do anything!
  • It’s user friendly
  • You can make hard boiled eggs, steam seafood, veggies, rice and more!

Recipe:

  • I filled the basin with water
  • I placed the sole into the bottom tier with dill
  • I placed my vegetable medley (I purchased it pre-cut and pre-washed): carrots, broccoli, cauliflower, onions, red peppers, yellow peppers, pea pods). I seasoned them with metabolism-boosting chilli pepper flakes.
  • I placed my pre-cut & pre-washed sweet potatoes into the top tier. I sprinkled them with cinnamon.
  • I set the timer for 18 minutes
  • Then I did nothing. Not true, then I made Protein Ice Cream for dessert!
  • 18 minutes later, it was done. Easy!
  • I sent my sister these pictures. She was so impressed, I suspect it’s only a matter of time before she buys a steamer!

Steamed sole and vegetables with Gaspari Protein Ice Cream and matcha green tea

Yes! I did eat all of this! I like big portions because I hate feeling hungry. This is why I am an intermittent faster. For more information, please sign up for my FREE weekly Intermittent Fasting Tutorials.

Nutritional Info:

I ate 7.5 oz of sole, 3 oz of sweet potatoes, and 2 cups of mixed veggies:

  • calories: 405, fat: 3.6g, saturated fat: 0.8g, cholesterol: 144.6mg, sodium: 341.8mg, carbohydrates: 33.6g, fiber: 7.7g, sugars: 11.3g, protein: 57.7g

Note: I like to drink Matcha Green tea because of its many health benefits, including its metabolism-enhancing benefits.

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

posts.title: Zucchini “Linguine”
posts.content:
Give up pasta? No way!

For all the pasta lovers out there: Never Fear because Faux Pasta is Here! Try my easy low-carb recipe for Zucchini Linguine tonight!

High carb pasta noodles are so last season! You might as well just glue those pasta noodles to your butt and thighs, because that’s exactly where they go when you eat them!

Quick Facts:

  • Cheesecake Factory’s Tomato Basil Pasta with Chicken has 1660 calories and 135 grams of carbohydrates!
  • Dr. Sara Solomon’s Zucchini Linguine (with Chicken) has 255 calories and only 6.9 grams of active carbohydrates.

Jump on the zucchini noodles bandwagon with me!

Easy Recipe:

Ingredients

1. Make the Zucchini Noodles

  • Wash a medium-sized zucchini, but you don’t have to peel it if you like the green colour in your pasta. The peel contains a good portion of the zucchini’s vitamins and minerals, so eat the peel!
  • Place the zucchini in your Spiral Vegetable Slicer (refer to my photo) and turn the crank.
    • If you don’t have a spiral vegetable slicer, I strongly recommend you get one, especially considering they are only $30 on amazon.com. Otherwise, you can use a mandolin or a vegetable peeler, neither of which are as quick or as neat-o as the spiral vegetable slicer).

2. Grill your boneless/skinless chicken breast in a non-stick skillet (or use non-stick cooking spray). If you are not in the mood to grill chicken, or if you are bereft of kitchen skills and fear giving yourself salmonella poisoning, then just buy it already made at the grocery store. Put the cooked chicken aside.

3. Toss the following into a clean non-stick skillet on medium heat (in this order):

  • 2 tsp of Extra Virgin Olive Oil (or use PAM non-stick cooking spray if you are trying to cut back on fat calories)
  • The zucchini noodles (~1.5 cups). I let them cook for 3 minutes before adding the next ingredients
  • 2 TBSP of Eden Organics Crushed Tomatoes (it is a “no sodium” sauce)
  • 4 oz of the chicken
  • garnish with lemon juice, black pepper, oregano, and/or your favourite salt-free seasoning.

4. Plate the dish. Sprinkle 1 tsp of Nutritional Yeast, which will impart a cheesy flavour. It’s dairy free.

Nutritional Information:

calories: 255, fat: 12.3g, saturated fat: 1.5g, cholesterol: 75 mg, sodium: 78.1mg, carbohydrates: 10.4 g, fiber: 3.5 g, NET CARBS: 6.9g, sugars: 10 g, protein: 30.6g

Compare this to the Cheesecake Factory’s “Tomato Basil Pasta with Chicken”, which has 1660 calories, 17 g of fat, 17 g of saturated fat and 135 g of carbs!

Jamie did a beautiful job making this meal! Look at her masterpiece!

And For Guilt-Free Dessert:

Yummy Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough! I recommend heating these Protein Bars in the microwave for 15 seconds to make them a guilt-free high protein gooey cookie!

posts.title: Banana Pancakes
posts.content:
Banana Perfection is right!

These look amazing, but they taste even better than they look! Nom nom nom!

Recipe:

In a Magic Bullet (or blender), blend the following:

  • 3/4 cup of egg whites
  • 1/2 scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Whey (Banana flavour)
  • 1/3 cup of gluten-free rolled oats
  • dash (1/2 tsp) of cinnamon

Place the batter onto a non-stick skillet over medium heat (or use non-stick cooking spray)

Flip the pancake (with a big spatula) after a few minutes (when you can see the bottom has turned golden brown). Cook the opposite side for a few minutes until it also turns golden brown.

Plate the pancake and drizzle with sugar-free/calorie-free pancake syrup: Walden Farms Calorie Free Pancake Syrup

Nutritional Information:

For one pancake with the calorie-free syrup:

  • calories: 225, fat: 5.3g, saturated fat: 0.3g, cholesterol: 25mg, sodium: 390.1mg, carbohydrates: 29.4g, fiber: 6.5g, NET CARBS: 22.9g, sugars: 1.7g, protein: 36.7g

Compare this to an equivalent serving size of IHOP’s “Buttermilk Pancakes” with “Regular Old Fashioned Maple Pancake Syrup”

  • calories: 424, fat: 10g, saturated fat: 4g, cholesterol: 46mg, sodium: 1075mg, carbohydrates: 73g, fiber: 2g, NET CARBS: 71g, sugars: 26g, protein 8g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations about the ingredients I used in this recipe by clicking on my Ingredient Encyclopedia!

Childhood Obesity: A Growing Problem

The  statistics about the growing obesity rates among children in America are quite alarming. Since 1980, obesity prevalence among children and adolescents has almost TRIPLED!1 In fact, 12.5 million children and adolescents in America are obese.1

Childhood obesity can have a harmful effect on the body. Obese children are more likely to have2:

  • High blood pressure and high cholesterol, both of which  are risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD).
  • Increased risk of impaired glucose tolerance, insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes.3
  • Breathing problems, such as sleep apnea, and asthma.4,5
  • Joint problems and musculoskeletal discomfort.4,6
  • Fatty liver disease, gallstones, and gastro-esophageal reflux (heartburn).3,4
  • Obese children and adolescents have a greater risk of social and psychological problems, such as discrimination and poor self-esteem, which can continue into adulthood.3,7,8
  • Obese children are more likely to become obese adults.9, 10, 11  Adult obesity is associated with a number of serious health conditions including heart disease, diabetes, and some cancers.12
  • If children are overweight, obesity in adulthood is likely to be more severe.13

Tips to Combat the Childhood Obesity Epidemic:

  • Provide plenty of veggies & fruits. My mom used to pre-wash, cut and serve the veggies and fruit in glass dishes. She would strategically place these dishes on the kitchen counter when my sister and I would get home from school. She knew we were ravenous and ready to “pig out” when we got home, so she was prepared.
  • Limit sugary junk food. A perfect example would be replacing sugary breakfast cereal with my recipe for Banana Perfection Pancakes. Replace sugary granola bars with high protein Quest Bars. Replace sugary Reese’s Peanut Butter Cups with Quest Protein Peanut Butter Cups.
  • Avoid sugary soda pop. If your child refuses to give up soda pop, I recommend Zevia (calorie-free, sugar free pop sweetened with stevia). I also recommend this as a dentist! Do you have any idea how much rampant decay I see every week on children and teenagers’ teeth because of sugary soda pop?
  • Get them involved in enjoyable activities, such as “family Wii Dance Night”, outdoor jump rope, local soccer leagues, etc.
  • Pre-pack school lunch boxes the night before and ensure they are involved with the healthy selections. The more involved the child is with the grocery shopping and meal preparations, the more likely they will want to eat their own ideas!
  • Throw away junk food in your fridge, freezer and pantries. A household full of healthy food will be a household that eats healthy food.
  • If you eat out at restaurants, avoid fast food joints.

 References:

  1. NCHS Health E-Stat. Prevalence of Obesity Among Children and Adolescents: United States, Trends 1963-1965 Through 2007-2008 by Cynthia Ogden, Ph.D., and Margaret Carroll, M.S.P.H., Division of Health and Nutrition Examination Surveys: http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/hestat/obesity_child_07_08/obesity_child_07_08.htm
  2. http://www.cdc.gov/obesity/childhood/basics.html
  3. Whitlock EP, Williams SB, Gold R, Smith PR, Shipman SA. Screening and interventions for childhood overweight: a summary of evidence for the US Preventive Services Task Force.Pediatrics. 2005;116(1):e125—144.
  4. Han JC, Lawlor DA, Kimm SY. Childhood obesity. Lancet. May 15 2010;375(9727):1737—1748.
  5. Sutherland ER. Obesity and asthma. Immunol Allergy Clin North Am. 2008;28(3):589—602, ix.
  6. Taylor ED, Theim KR, Mirch MC, et al. Orthopedic complications of overweight in children and adolescents. Pediatrics. Jun 2006;117(6):2167—2174.
  7. Dietz W. Health consequences of obesity in youth: Childhood predictors of adult disease.Pediatrics 1998;101:518—525.
  8. Swartz MB and Puhl R. Childhood obesity: a societal problem to solve. Obesity Reviews 2003; 4(1):57—71.
  9. Biro FM, Wien M. Childhood obesity and adult morbidities. Am J Clin Nutr. May 2010;91(5):1499S—1505S.
  10. Whitaker RC, Wright JA, Pepe MS, Seidel KD, Dietz WH. Predicting obesity in young adulthood from childhood and parental obesity. N Engl J Med 1997;37(13):869—873.
  11. Serdula MK, Ivery D, Coates RJ, Freedman DS. Williamson DF. Byers T. Do obese children become obese adults? A review of the literature. Prev Med 1993;22:167—177.
  12. National Institutes of Health. Clinical Guidelines on the Identification, Evaluation, and Treatment of Overweight and Obesity in Adults: the Evidence Report. Bethesda, MD: National Institutes of Health, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services; 1998.
  13. Freedman DS, Khan LK, Dietz WH, Srinivasan SR, Berenson GS. Relationship of childhood overweight to coronary heart disease risk factors in adulthood: The Bogalusa Heart Study.Pediatrics 2001;108:712—718.

posts.title: Protein Donuts
posts.content:
Pumpkin Spice it Up!

I confess I’ve had a few Krispy Kreme Donuts back in the day. I can vouch it’s nothing more than a circular lump of glazed dough that you might as well just superglue to your thigh.

So I decided to invent a healthy protein donut!

Recipe:

This recipe yields ~ 7 donuts

1. Preparatory Steps:

  • Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F
  • Spray your donut pan with non-stick cooking spray

2. Mix all the dry ingredients in a bowl:

  • 1 scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Cinnamon Bun Whey
  • 3/4 of a cup of quinoa flour
  • 1 tsp of baking powder
  • 1 tsp of baking soda
  • 1/4 tsp of salt (I like Himalayan salt)
  • 1 tsp of cinnamon
  • 1/2 tsp of nutmeg

3. Mix all the wet ingredients in another bowl:

  • 2 eggs
  • 1/4 tsp vanilla extract
  • 1/4 cup of canned pumpkin
  • 1/4 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk
  • 2 TBSP of extra virgin coconut oil.

4. Whisk the moist ingredients into the dry ingredients. Do not over mix. Stir until just combined (or else the donuts will be rubbery)

5. Pour the batter into a large Ziploc bag. Cut an opening in 1 corner of the bag and pipe the batter into each donut mold (but only 1/2 to 3/4 full). If you overfill each mold, the donut holes will close when you bake it.

6. Bake for 8-10 minutes or until the donuts spring back when you touch them. Let them cool before icing them.

7. Make the icing:

Cream Cheese Icing Recipe:

This yields enough icing for 4 donuts.

  • 1/2 scoop BSN Syntha-6 Whey (Cinnamon Bun Flavour)
  • 1 TBSP unsweetened vanilla almond milk
  • 2 TBSP vegan cream cheese , such as Toffuti. (I melted it in the microwave first for 5 seconds before adding it) or you can use a soy-free version, such as “Daiya Dairy-Free Cream Cheese Style Spread”. You could also use low fat cottage cheese!
  • Mix these ingredients together (by hand) to create the icing.

Chocolate Icing Recipe:

This yields enough icing for 3 donuts

  • 3/4 scoop BSN ISOBURN whey (Chocolate Milkshake Flavour)
  • 1 TBSP extra virgin coconut oil
  • 1 TBSP unsweetened vanilla almond milk
  • Mix these ingredients together (by hand) to create the icing.

8. Ice your Donuts (once cooled). I placed my iced donuts into the fridge for 5 minutes to set the icing. They are best served fresh. I did, however, keep mine in the fridge for a few days, and they still tasted great.

Pumpkin Spice Protein Donuts with Cream Cheese or Chocolate Icing

Nutritional Information:

For one Protein donut (no icing):

  • calories: 140, fat: 7.2g, saturated fat: 4.4 g, cholesterol: 77.1mg, sodium: 65mg, carbohydrates: 11.6g, fiber: 2.2g, sugars: 0.64 g, protein: 6.8g

For 1/4 of  Cream Cheese Icing:

  • calories: 33, fat: 1.4 g, saturated fat: 0.45 g, cholesterol: 8.1mg, sodium: 36.6mg, carbohydrates: 2.15g, fiber: 0.65g, sugars: 0.25 g, protein: 2.9g

For 1/3 of Chocolate Icing:

  • calories: 74, fat: 5.2g, saturated fat: 4.5g, cholesterol: 2.5mg, sodium: 46.3mg, carbohydrates: 1.3g, fiber: 0.5g, sugars: 0.5 g, protein: 5g

Compare this to Krispy Kreme’s:

  • “Pumpkin Spice Cake Donut”: calories: 340, fat: 18g, saturated fat: 4.5 g, 6 g trans fat, cholesterol: 20 mg, sodium: 300mg, carbohydrates: 42 g, fiber: 1g, sugars: 26 g, protein: 3g
  • “Chocolate Iced Glazed Donut”: calories: 250, fat: 12g, saturated fat: 3 g, cholesterol: 5mg, sodium: 100mg, carbohydrates: 33g, fiber: 0g, sugars: 21 g, protein: 3g

This is Krispy Kreme’s pumpkin spice donut. It has 33 g of carbs, 21 g of sugar and only 3 g of protein. 


Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Mom’s Spicy Chicken & Broccoli
posts.content:
My mom just made me a healthy meal: spicy chicken & broccoli!

It’s easy, delicious, healthy, high in protein, low in sodium and low carb!

Mom’s Recipe:

  • Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F.
  • Place your boneless, skinless chicken breasts on a non-stick cookie sheet (or spray with non-stick cooking spray to make clean-up easier).
  • Use a basting brush to lightly coat the breasts with Extra Virgin Olive Oil. (~1 tsp per breast)
  • Season the chicken breasts with Mrs. Dash Salt-Free “Fiesta Lime” Seasoning Blend.
  • Place into the oven for 30 minutes.
  • For the sake of convenience, I recommend purchasing Microwave Steam-in-bag Broccoli Florets. It only takes 3 minutes in the microwave (just pierce the bag).  They are already washed and cut for you.
  • Once the chicken is finished, cut it into small strips.
  • Place 6oz of chicken into a bowl with 2 cups of broccoli. Add 2 TBSP of spicy salsa. Season with black pepper. Serve & Enjoy! Place the left-overs into the fridge for tomorrow’s meals.

Nutritional Information:

calories: 270, fat: 7.7 g, saturated fat: 0.7 g, sodium: 235mg, carbohydrates: 9.5g, fiber 4 g, NET CARBS: 5.5g, sugars 4.5 g, protein: 43 g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed explanations of the ingredients used in this in my Ingredient Encyclopaedia.

posts.title: Cookies & Cream Protein Ice Cream
posts.content:
I scream!

AMAZING because it’s…

  • YUMMY!
  • High protein
  • Low fat
  • Low carb & very low sugar
  • Ready in 20 minutes
  • Minimal ingredients
  • A perfect “clean cheat”

Version 1

Recipe (Version 1):

Blend the following in a Magic Bullet:

  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk
  • 3/4 scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Whey in Cookies and Cream Flavour
  • 1/4 tsp of gluten-free xanthan gum. (it’s a thickening agent). Optional: If you want your ice cream to be creamier, then also add 1/4 tsp of Guar Gum (I didn’t bother with the guar gum because I didn’t have any in my pantry).
MAKE THE ICE CREAM:
Step 1: Buy an Ice Cream Machine. I got mine at the rainforest place for ~$50 here. Best thing money can buy. I use mine ALL the time except when I don’t use it.
Step 2: Watch my “How to Use an Ice Cream Machine Tootorial Video” or just read my instructions here.

Nutritional Information:

Calories: 188, fat: 7.1g, saturated fat: 1.7g, cholesterol: 45mg, sodium: 262.9mg, carbohydrates: 19g, dietary fiber: 9.3g, NET CARBS: 9.7g, sugars: 3g, protein: 17.3g

Compare this to Nestle’s Oreo Ice Cream, which has over 24 ingredients, 15 g of fat, 26 g of carbs and 19 g of sugar per serving.

Recipe (Version 2):

I love version 2 because it’s VERY CREAMY!

Version 2 is SUPER CREAMY!

Blend the following in a Magic Bullet:

  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk
  • 3/4 scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Whey in Cookies & Cream Flavour
  • 1 TBSP of low fat cottage cheese
  • 1 TBSP nonfat plain Greek yogurt
  • 1 tsp vanilla extract

Pour this into your ice cream machine for 15-20 minutes.

ENJOY!

Nutritional Information:

Calories: 215, fat: 7.2g, saturated fat: 1.7g, cholesterol: 46.9mg, sodium: 264.1mg, carbohydrates: 14.3g, dietary fiber: 3g, NET CARBS: 11.3g, sugars: 4.4g, protein: 21.8g

posts.title: Chocolate Brownie Chunks Protein Ice Cream
posts.title_plain: Chocolate Brownie Chunks Protein Ice Cream
posts.content:
IceCREAMergency!

Question: What’s better than a Dairy Queen (DQ) Brownie Batter Blizzard*?

Answer: My healthy version! It tastes equally delicious and is high in protein (or as I like to call it, proteineous). Unlike the DQ version, it doesn’t have ridiculously high calories, high carbs or an exorbitant amount of sugar. Did you know the DQ version has 640 calories, 88 g of carbs and 71 g of sugar? And that’s just the small size! The large one is nearly 1400 calories! Holy Fat Cells, Batman!

Question: Why is this Chocolate Brownie Chunks Protein Ice Cream so amazing?

Answer:

  • Umm…look at it! DROOL. Brownie chunks in a creamy chocolate soft serve!
  • Low carb and low sugar (perfect for diabetics)
  • Only requires 20 minutes to make and 4 ingredients
  • It’s high in protein. More specifically, it’s high in casein protein. Casein protein digests SLOWLY, providing a slow-release amino stream for an 8 hour period.  This means it can be used to help repair muscle and prevent muscle breakdown while you sleep for 8 hours.  Therefore, the optimal time to take it would be before bed.
  • It prevents you from cheating on your healthy diet with something that will spike your insulin (thereby interfering with your fat burning attempts) and contribute to dental decay (I had to say that last one because I’m a dentist).
Question: Why is this also called Bodybuilding.com Protein Ice Cream?
 .
Answer: Because it is made with my 2 favourite products that I regularly order from Bodybuilding.com:
  • Bodybuilding.com 100% Casein – Chocolate
  • Quest Nutrition Bars  - Chocolate Brownie

Question: Is it necessary to have an ice cream maker for this recipe?

Answer: No.

  1. I elected to purchase an ice cream maker from Canadian Tire – well… um…because it was on sale for 50 bucks and I live in Canada, duh and eh. Did I mention it was on sale? Yes I did (oops) and now that I just re-read that, it’s obvious I have misfiring neurons in my hippocampus. But I digress. I am well aware that Canadian Tire, (a.k.a “so much more than just tires”) does not exist in the Excited States of America, which sucks like 17 vacuums for Americans. And yes, all 17 vacuums are required to ensure the necessary suckage force. Fortunately, you can get all 17 of these vacuums on sale at Canadian Tire. What was my point? Oh yeah. If you want to get an ice cream maker for an equally good price, you are in luck because I found the exact same model for only $45 on amazon.com (the website, not the rainforest). Here it is: Cuisinart ICE-21 Frozen Yogurt-Ice Cream & Sorbet Maker, White
  2. Here is another way to make ice cream, using 2 Ziploc bags.
    1. Stuff a HUGE Ziploc bag half-full with ice. Add 6 TBSP of Kosher Salt  (or rock salt) and mix.
    2. Add all the ingredients used in this recipe (see below) into a small Ziploc bag and seal it.
    3. Bury the small Ziploc bag inside the salty ice in the large Ziploc bag. Seal the large bag.
    4. Shake the bags vigorously for 5-15 minutes until ice cream forms! (hold with a towel to prevent frost bite).
      • Note: When you add salt to the ice, it lowers the freezing point of the ice, so more energy has to be absorbed from the environment for the ice to melt. This makes the ice colder than it was before, which is how your ice cream freezes.
      • Note: Kosher & rock salt have larger crystals than table salt. Larger crystals take longer to dissolve in water around the ice, which allows for even cooling of the ice cream.

Recipe:

Make sure you watch my Video TOOTorial on how to use an ice cream machine.

Add the following to a Magic Bullet.

  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk
  • 1 scoop of Bodybuilding.com 100% Casein – Chocolate. If you are allergic to casein protein, then substitute with whey protein. If you are lactose-intolerant, then purchase a whey protein isolate that is labelled 100% lactose-free. You can peruse your whey options at Bodybuilding.com
  • 1/4 tsp of gluten-free xanthan gum. (it’s a thickening agent).
  • Optional: If you want your ice cream to be creamy, then also add 1/4 tsp of Guar Gum (I didn’t bother with the guar gum because I didn’t have any in my pantry, so there).
Remove your ice cream bowl from the freezer (you are supposed to keep it in the freezer all the time… and at least for 24 hours before the first time you use it. Yeah, I was pretty angry about waiting 24 hours the first time too). Set the bowl onto your ice cream stand and assemble the ice cream maker according to the directions.
  • Turn the Ice Cream Maker to the ON position.
  • Pour your mixture into the spinning ice cream bowl. Try not to become hypnotized by the swirling future ice cream.
  • Set the timer for 20 minutes.
While you are waiting, make the “Moist Chunks of Brownie”. Don’t worry Betty Crocker, it’s easier than 2 + 2.
  • Get a Quest Nutrition Bar: Chocolate Brownie.
  • Open the package and cut it in half
  • You only need to use half (save the other half for one of those moments when you’re so hungry you could eat your elbows).
  • Use scissors to cut the Quest bar into “tiny little chewy brownie pieces”
When there are only 5 minutes remaining on your timer, add the brownie pieces to your ice cream maker. Because I’m fancy, I like to save a few brownie pieces with which I garnish my ice cream after having scooped it into an elegant dish. Also, because I’m fancy, I did not end that prior sentence with a preposition, since that is something up with which I will not put.
Now that you’ve scooped your ice cream into a dish & garnished it with “brownie chunks”, it’s time to eat it! But no need to worry because the brownie chunks in this ice cream don’t go into your guilt chamber. No siree bob. It’s so high in fiber, it just passes right through you like fiberrhea. For more information on Quest Nutrition Products and to watch my entertaining “Quest Taste Test Videos”, please click here.
.

Nutritional Information:

My version:

  • calories: 275, fat: 9.5g, saturated fat: 1g, cholesterol: 17mg, sodium: 560mg, carbohydrates: 19g, dietary fiber: 11g, NET CARBS: 8g, sugars: 2.5g, protein: 36g

Compare this to a small “Chocolate Xtreme Blizzard” from Dairy Queen:

  • calories: 640, fat: 28g, saturated fat: 15g, cholesterol: 65mg, sodium: 370mg, carbohydrates: 88g, dietary fiber: 3g, NET CARBS: 85g, sugars: 71g, protein: 12g

 My version wins!

posts.title: Protein Peanut Butter Cup Fluff
posts.content:
Fluff!

Protein PB Cup Fluff is the ultimate Bodybuilding.com Dessert Recipe!

It features 2 ingredients you can order from Bodybuilding.com:

  1. Quest Protein Peanut Butter Cups 
  2. Bodybuilding.com 100% Casein  - Vanilla (I am addicted to all 3 flavours of Bodybuilding.com’s Casein Protein! I use it at night before bed, especially because I’m an intermittent faster!)

Advantages:

  • Only requires 10 minutes to make and 5 ingredients
  • Low Carb and Low Sugar (diabetic friendly)
  • High in protein
  • Delicious
  • Features Quest Nutrition’s Guilt-Free Protein Peanut Butter Cups! Watch my video taste tests to see & learn about all Quest Products!

What is Casein Protein?

I’m sure you have heard of Whey Protein, which is used immediately post-workout because it digests quickly to help you build muscle.  Casein protein, however, digests SLOWLY, providing a slow-release amino stream for an 8 hour period.  This means it can be used to help repair muscle and prevent muscle breakdown while you sleep for 8 hours.  Therefore, the optimal time to take it would be before bed.

Another option is to mix it with whey protein (50/50) to create a powerful dual-function protein cocktail.

Recipe:

Step 1: Add the following to a large bowl and mix with an electric hand mixer for 10 minutes (this creates the fluff):

  • 1 scoop of Bodybuilding.com 100% Casein  - Vanilla
  • 1 TBSP of all-natural crunchy peanut butter (to save on fat calories, substitute with PB2).
  • 1 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk
  • 1/4 tsp of gluten-free xanthan gum (it’s a thickening agent)

Step 2: Cut 1 Quest Protein PB cup into tiny pieces using a sharp knife
  • Pour the fluff into a dessert bowl
  • Garnish with the PB cup pieces
  • Serve and Enjoy! It yields quite a large portion, so unless you are He-Man, I recommend eating half and placing the other half in the fridge for the following evening.

Nutritional Information:

This recipe yields:

  • 400 calories, 23 g of fat, 5.5 g of saturated fat, cholesterol: 17.5 mg, sodium: 510 mg, carbohydrates: 15 g, fiber: 5.5 g, NET CARBS: 9.5 g, sugars: 3.5 g, protein: 40 g

This is a colossal portion (perfect for all the muscle-building manly men). I, however, am a lady and was content eating half:

  • 200 calories, 11.5 g of fat, 2.75 g of saturated fat, cholesterol: 8.75 mg, sodium: 255 mg, carbohydrates: 7.5 g, fiber: 2.75, NET CARBS: 4.75, sugars: 1.88 g, protein: 20 g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: NO-BAKE Chocolate Haystacks
posts.content:
Drumroll please… Chocolate Haystacks!

  • High in protein
  • Low in Sugar
  • Gluten-Free
  • Easy to make (only 5 ingredients)
  • Delicious

Recipe:

  • Place the following into a bowl:
    • 3/4 of a scoop of BSN Syntha-6 Whey Protein in Chocolate Cake Batter
    • 1/3 cup of gluten-free rolled oats.
    • 1 TBSP of nut butter.  I used all-natural crunchy peanut butter (to save on fat calories, use PB2)
    • 2 TBSP of organic reduced fat shredded coconut
    • dash of cinnamon
    • optional: sweeten with stevia, luo han guo, vanilla extract, or Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free Pancake Syrup (I personally find the recipe is sweet enough – so I don’t bother adding any sweeteners).
  • Add a sparing amount of water whilst mixing the abovementioned ingredients. Don’t add too much water. You want to end up with a “dense protein mixture”.
  • You have 4 options to make the haystacks:
  1. Dehydrator Option:
    • Make into haystack shapes on a Paraflexx  non stick drying sheet.
      • Dehydrate at 95-105 degrees until dry on the outside and moist on the inside.I left mine in my dehydrator for 4 and 1/2 hours.
      • If you don’t eat them all, store them in an air tight container.
      • I was able to make 8 haystacks using these quantities. Feel free to make bigger or smaller haystacks.
      • I prefer this option (it’s easier to transport the finished haystacks with this option. I find the no-bake methods make the haystacks a bit tacky and gooey).
      • I decided to invest in the smallest and least expensive Excalibur Food Dehydrator.
      • I saw inexpensive circular food dehydrators the other day at Canadian Tire for $30. I found them on amazon here!
  2. Refrigerator Option:
    • place the haystacks on some parchment or wax paper on a plate
    • place into the fridge for 4 hours
  3. Freezer Option:
    • if you are too impatient to wait for your haystacks to set in the fridge, then throw them into the freezer for 30 minutes.
  4. Oven Option:
  • Use your oven at the lowest temperature setting possible (100 to 150 degrees)
  • Place the cookies onto a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper or a Silpat mat.
  • Place into the oven and keep the door open. Use a fan if your oven has one (to minimize condensation)
  • You don’t have to leave it in the oven as long as you would in the dehydrator. Check after an hour.

Nutritional Information:

This recipe (using real PB and not PB2) yields approximately 8 haystacks and amounts to:

  • calories: 307, fat: 17.8g, saturated fat: 5.3g, cholesterol: 41.2mg, sodium: 165 mg, carbohydrates: 37.6 g, fiber: 9.1g, NET CARBS: 28.5g, sugars: 3.2 g, protein: 25.7 g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed descriptions about the ingredients used in this recipe in my Ingredient Encyclopedia.

posts.title: Oatmeal Cookies
posts.content:
Hey Cookie Monsters!

Zillions of bodybuilders and fitness models have the following in their meal plan:

  • rolled oats
  • almond butter
  • whey protein
  • cinnamon

So why not combine all of these ingredients and make warm and chewy cookies?

Just look at them!!!

These are awesome because they are:

  • Perfect for anyone who exercises and eats healthy
  • High in protein
  • Low in Sugar
  • Easy to make (only 5 ingredients)
  • Delicious

Recipe:

Place the following into a bowl:

  • 1 scoop of BSN ISOBURN Whey (vanilla ice cream flavour). 
  • 3/4 cup of gluten-free rolled oats.
  • 1 TBSP of nut butter.  Feel free to use all natural peanut butter or almond butter.
  • 5 g (that would be 1 tsp) of raw cacao nibs. You can substitute with >70% dark chocolate chips.
  • Dash of cinnamon
  • Sweeten with 1 TBSP Walden Farms Calorie Free/Sugar Free Pancake Syrup. You could substitute with vanilla stevia, luo han guo, or vanilla extract.
  • Add a sparing amount of water whilst mixing the abovementioned ingredients. Don’t add too much water. You want to end up with a “dense protein boulder”.

Make into cookie shapes and place onto a Paraflexx  non stick drying sheet in your food dehydrator. I decided to invest in the smallest and least expensive Excalibur Food Dehydrator.

  • Dehydrate at 95-105 degrees until dry on the outside and moist on the inside.  I left mine in my dehydrator for 4 and 1/2 hours.
  • If you don’t eat them all, store them in an air tight container.
  • I was able to make 7 cookies using these quantities. Feel free to make bigger or smaller cookies.
What if you don’t have a food dehydrator and you don’t want to buy one?
  • Use your oven at the lowest temperature setting possible (100 to 150 degrees)
  • Place the cookies onto a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper or a Silpat mat.
  • Place into the oven and keep the door open. Use a fan if your oven has one (to minimize condensation)
  • You don’t have to leave it in the oven as long as you would in the dehydrator. Check after 1 to 2 hours.

Nutritional Information:

This recipe yields approximately 7 cookies and amounts to:
  • calories: 309, fat: 17.2g, saturated fat: 3g, cholesterol: 10mg, sodium: 199.4 mg, carbohydrates: 60.6 g, fiber: 13.5g, NET CARBS: 47.1, sugars: 5.1 g, protein: 34.8 g
One cookie would be:
  • calories: 43.7, fat: 2.5g, saturated fat: 0.4 g, cholesterol: 1.4 mg, sodium: 28.5 mg, carbohydrates: 8.7 g, fiber: 1.9 g, NET CARBS: 6.8 g, sugars: 0.7 g, protein: 5 g

Ingredient Information:

=> Find detailed descriptions about the ingredients used in this recipe in my Ingredient Encyclopedia.

Too Busy to Make Cookies?

Then I recommend Quest Nutrition’s Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough Bar. It tastes like a cookie. I suggest you heat it in the microwave for 15 seconds to make a warm gooey chocolate chip cookie! NOM NOM YUM YUM!

posts.title: Eggplant McMuffin
posts.content:
McWhat?

What is an Egg McMuffin? It’s McDonald’s fast food breakfast sandwich, consisting of an English muffin, a fried egg, processed cheese, liquid margarine and Canadian bacon.  Here is list of reasons why you should think before eating an Egg McMuffin:

  • Processed ingredients
  • Laced with preservatives
  • High in sodium
  • High in cholesterol
  • Prepared using hydrogenated liquid margarine
  • First 5 ingredients include:  enriched flour, high fructose corn syrup and sugar

Did you know that one Egg McMuffin contains 820 mg of sodium (34% of your daily sodium intake) and 260 mg of cholesterol (87% of your daily cholesterol intake)*? And the reality is that you will probably order 2 of these, which means 600 calories, 1640 mg of sodium 520 mg of cholesterol!  It’s no secret that foods high in cholesterol can increase your risk of a heart attack and foods high in sodium can lead to high blood pressure. So try my healthy eggplantastic version instead!

 

This recipe uses Daiya Vegan Cheese, which is free of dairy (casein, whey and lactose), soy, gluten, eggs, rice, peanuts and tree nuts (except coconut oil).  It is also cholesterol & trans-fat free and contains no preservatives.  You can find it in the cheese section of your grocery store. I like to use Diaya instead of skim cheese because cheese gives me the back door trots. Feel free to use skim cheese if you don’t have this problem!

Recipe:

This recipe is Low Carb, Low Fat, Dairy-free, Gluten-free, High in Protein, and Diabetic Friendly

Place the following onto a non-stick skillet (or use healthy non-stick cooking spray):

  • Extra lean ground chicken.  Once cooked, measure 1 oz
  • Clean the skillet and grill 2 slices (1 cup) of eggplant (slice it to resemble the shape of an English muffin).  Flip to ensure both sides are cooked. Place these aside on a plate
  • Then place 1/2 cup of egg whites mixed with 1 TBSP of vegan Daiya Cheese on the skillet – flip to ensure cooked. Season with pepper.
Place the cheese omelette and chicken between the 2 eggplant “buns”.  Enjoy!

Nutritional Info:

Sara’s Eggplant McMuffin: calories: 150, fat: 3.9 g, saturated fat: 2.9 g, cholesterol: 21.4 mg, sodium: 263 mg, carbohydrates: 8.7 g, fiber: 4.8 g, sugars: 3.2 g, protein: 20.6 g

McDonald’s Egg McMuffin*: calories: 300, fat: 12 g, saturated fat: 5 g, cholesterol: 260 mg, sodium: 820 mg, carbohydrates: 30g, fiber: 2 g, sugars: 3.0 g, protein: 18.0 g

Ingredient Information:

posts.title: Shrimp & Pasta
posts.content:
Presenting my GUILT-FREE colossal portion of Shrimp Alfredo Pasta with Cheeze!   Shazam and abracadabra!

Recipe Perks!
  • Low carb (only 8g net carbs)
  • Under 200 calories
  • Low sugar (only 1 g)
  • Diabetic friendly
  • High in fiber
  • Gluten-free
  • Dairy-free
  • Very delicious!
  • Super easy to make!

Recipe:

Step 1: Prepare the Macaroni

  • Drain and thoroughly rinse 1 package (8 oz) House Foods Tofu Shirataki Noodles Macaroni(USA Shoppers).  Canadian shoppers please click  Tofu Shirataki MACARONI.
    • This is a low calorie/low carb/gluten-free pasta alternative made from blending the root of the Konnyaku (a member of the yam family) and tofu.
  • Boil for 2-3 min and then dry very well (these are the instructions on the package but I skip this step because I’m lazy).
  • Because I hate fussing in the kitchen, I just toss the drained macaroni noodles into my non-stick skillet with the mushrooms, shrimp, alfredo sauce and vegan cheese.  Quick and easy!

Step 2: Add the fixins:

  • On a non-stick skillet (or use non-stick cooking spray):
    • grill 4 oz of shrimp with 1 cup of cremini mushrooms. (Feel free to substitute with chicken).
    • Add 1/8 of cup of Daiya vegan cheese (or if you prefer, add 1 TBSP of nutritional yeast).
    • add 2 TBSP of Walden Farms Calorie Free Pasta Sauce Alfredo.
  • Add black pepper
  • serve and enjoy!

Nutritional Information:

calories: 185, fat: 5.3g, saturated fat: 1.5g, cholesterol:  206.7mg, sodium:  577 mg, carbohydrates: 12.5g, dietary fiber:  4.5g, NET CARBS: 8g, sugars:  1 g, protein:  23.1 g
